[See also dibolN and dabiylN.] ＝ -A3- Also [Turtle-shell, or tortoise-shell;] the back, (IAar, S, Msb,) or skin, (M, K,) [meaning shell,] of the sea-tortoise [or turtle], (IAar, S, M, Msb, K,) or of the land-tortoise, (M, K,) of which are made combs, (IAar, TA,) and, as some say, signet-rings &c., (TA,) or of which bracelets are made: (S:) or the bones of the back of a certain marine beast, of which are made, (M, K,) by women, (M,) bracelets (M, K) and combs; and the combing wherewith removes nits and the scurf of the hair: (K:) or horns of which are made [the bracelets, or anklets, called] masaka: (En-Nadr, TA:) or a certain thing [or substance] resembling ivory: (Msb:) Th cites a poet as using the phrase caAtu AlcRabalaAt, forming the pl. of cabolN with A and t; but accord. to the citation of IAar, the word in this instance is AlrRabalaAt. (M.)

cibolN c
cibolN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

cabolapN c
cabolapN A piece of camels' or similar dung: (M, K:) because of its drying up. (M.) ― -b2- And A withering wind. (M, K.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
diyaArN maHatohaA baEodanaA kulRu cabolapK
[Abodes of which every withering wind had effaced the traces after they had been seen by us]. (M.)

cabolaMCu c
cabolaMCu A woman whose lip is dry. (O, K. *)

cubaAlN c
cubaAlN: see cubaAlapN. ＝ -A2- Also Ulcers that come forth in the side and penetrate into the inside; (K;) i. q. naqRaAbaAtN; and so dubaAlN, with d. (IAar, T.)

cabuwlN c
cabuwlN A calamity, or misfortune; (T, TA;) as also cabiylN↓ and ciYobilN↓: (Ibn-'Abbád, TA:) see 1. [See also cubayolapN, in the first paragraph, and below.]

cabiylN c
cabiylN: see cabolN, in three places: ― -b2- and cabuwlN.

cubaAlapN c
cubaAlapN (T, S, M, K) and cubRaAlapN↓ (T, K) A wick (T, S, M, K) that is lighted, (M,) or with which a lamp is lighted, or trimmed: (T:) or cubRaAlapN signifies a wick of which a portion is burnt: (Ham p. 81:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] cubaAlN↓ and cubRaAlN↓. (T, K, * TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce daAHuwlN.]

cubayolapN c
cubayolapN and [its pl.] cabaAYilu [or this is pl. of cabuwlN or cabiylN]: see 1.

cubRaAlN c
cubRaAlN: see cubaAlapN.

cubRaAlapN c
cubRaAlapN: see cubaAlapN.

caAbilN c
caAbilN Withering, or withered; losing, or having lost, its moisture. (TA.) ― -b2- Spear-shafts (qanFA) slender, and of which the liyT [or exterior part] adheres [firmly]: (M, K: * [for laASiqN biAlilRyTi, in the K, I read laASiqu AllRiyTi, as in the M:]) pl. cibRalN and cubulN. (M, K.) ― -b3- Lean, or emaciated: (Ham p. 788.) ― -b4- See also cabolN, in four places.

ciYobilN c
ciYobilN: see cabuwlN.

caHolN c
caHolN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and caHalN↓ (Msb) Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; or concealment of enmity, and violent hatred, in the heart; or retention of enmity in the heart, with watchfulness for an opportunity to indulge it or exercise it; syn. HiqodN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and [simply] enmity: (S, K:) or blood-revenge; or retaliation of murder or homicide; or a seeking to revenge, or avenge, or retaliate, blood; syn. vaOorN: or a desire, or seeking, for retaliation of a crime or of enmity: (K:) pl. (of the former) cuHuwlN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and (of the latter, Msb) OacoHaAlN. (Mgh, Msb, K.) One says, Talaba bicaHolihi, meaning bivaOorihi [i. e. He sought to obtain his bloodrevenge, or retaliation]. (S, Msb.) And Einodahu caHoliI [He owes me my blood-revenge], meaning he is the slayer of my relation. (A in art. vOr.) [See also a verse of Lebeed cited as an ex. of the preposition bi.]

caHalN c
caHalN: see the preceding paragraph.

1 caxarahu c
1. caxarahu, aor.
caxara
, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. cuxorN↓, (S, K,) or this is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is caxorN; (Msb;) and AidRaxarahu↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) of the measure AifotaEala, (S, Msb,) originally Aicotaxarahu, the t being changed into d, and the c being incorporated into it; and some of the Arabs say AicRaxarahu↓, which is allowable; but the former is more common; (Zj;) He hoarded it, treasured it, or laid it up for the future; reposited it, or stored it, in secret; (A;) or he prepared it, or provided it; (Msb;) for a time of need: (A, Msb:) or he chose it, or selected it, and (so in some copies of the K and in the TA, but in other copies of the K “ or ”) took it for himself, or prepared it. (K.) Some have made a distinction between cxr and dxr, saying that the former relates to the world to come, and the latter to the present world; but this is a manifest mistake. (MF and others.) ― -b2- caxara linafosihi HadiyvFA HasanFA (A) (tropical:) He reserved, or preserved, for himself [a good story, or the like]. (TA.) ― -b3- caxara mino Eadowihi (tropical:) [He (a horse) reserved somewhat of his run, i. e., power of running, or was sparing of it, for the time of need]. (M in art. Swn.) [See also mudRaxirN, below.] ― -b4- fulaAnN maA nuSoHFA yadRaxiru↓ (tropical:) [Such a one does not treasure in his heart good advice]. (A, TA.)

8 AidRaxara c and AicRaxara
8. AidRaxara AicRaxara: see 1, in three places.

cuxorN c
cuxorN: see 1: ― -b2- and see the next paragraph, in two places.

caxiyrapN c
caxiyrapN (S, A, Msb, K) and caxorN↓ (A, Msb, * K) A thing hoarded, treasured, or laid up; reposited, or stored, in secret; (A;) or prepared, or provided; (Msb;) for a time of need: (A, Msb:) or taken for one's self, or prepared: (K:) pl. of the former, caxaAYiru; (S, A, Msb;) and of the latter, OacoxaArN. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- You say, Einoda QllRehi jaEala maA lahu cuxorFA↓ and caxiyrapF (tropical:) [He made his wealth to be a store in the hands of God, by applying it to pious uses]. (A.) ― -b3- And OaEomaAlu AlmuWmini caxaAYiru (tropical:) [The works of the believer are things laid up for the time of need, i. e. the day of resurrection]. (A.)

caAxirN c
caAxirN (assumed tropical:) Fat; as an epithet. (AA, K.)

UicoxirN c
UicoxirN [A kind of sweet rush; juncus odoratus; or schœnanthum;] a certain plant, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or herb, (K,) well known, (Msb,) in form resembling the kawolaAn [or papyrus-plant], (Mgh,) sweet-smelling, (K,) or of pungent odour; (Mgh, Msb;) which, when it dries, becomes white; (Msb;) used for roofing houses, over the wood, and for graves: (TA:) it has a root hidden in the ground, slender, pungent in odour; and is like the straight stalks of the kawolaAn [or papyrus-plant], save that it is wider, and smaller in the kuEuwb [which means either the joints or the internodal portions]; and it has a fruit resembling the brooms of reeds, but more slender, and smaller: it is ground, and is an ingredient in perfumes: it grows in rugged
and in smooth grounds; but seldom does more than one grow on the same spot: when it dries, it becomes white: (AHn:) 'Iyád asserts that its C is a radical letter; but this is a mistake: (MF:) the n. un. is UicoxirapN; (S;) which is applied to a single plant, (AHn,) or to a single fascicle thereof. (Mgh.)

micoxarN c
micoxarN (tropical:) The [part of the intestines called] Eafaj: (TA:) [its pl.] macaAxiru is also explained as signifying the intestines; and bellies; (S, K;) and veins: (K:) or the lower part of the belly: (As, K:) or the parts of the inside of a beast in which he stores his fodder and water. (A.) You say fulaAnN malaOa macaAxirahu (tropical:) Such a one filled the lower parts of his belly. (As.) And malaOati AldRaAbRapu macaAxirahaA (tropical:) The beast satiated itself. (TA.) And tamalRaOato macaAxiruhu (tropical:) He became satiated. (A.) And malaOa lanaA fiI macaAxirihi EadaAwapF (tropical:) [He filled his heart with enmity towards us]. (A.)

mudRaxirN mdxr
mudRaxirN, or mucRaxirN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) (assumed tropical:) A horse that reserves his run; expl. by AlmuboqiI liHuDorihi: (AO, K, TA:) [Freytag's reading of mucaxRarN for mudRaxirN or mucRaxirN, and his proposed emendation, of AlmanoqiIRu for AlmuboqiI, both taken from the TK, but neither found by me in any copy of the K, are evidently wrong: see caxara mino Eadowihi, above:] such is the misowaAT, a horse “ that will not give what he has without the whip: the fem. is with p. (TA.)

1 carRa c
1. carRa, (T, S, M, A, &c.,) aor.
carura
, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. carRN, (S, M, K, &c.,) He sprinkled, or scattered, salt (T, * S, A, Msb, K) upon flesh-meat, and pepper upon a mess of crumbled bread with broth, (A,) and a medicament (S, A) into the eye, (A,) and grain (S, A, K) upon the ground, (A,) &c.; (T, Msb, K;) as also carocara↓, inf. n. carocarapN: (K:) he took a thing with the ends of his fingers and sprinkled it upon a thing. (M.) You say, carRa Eayonahu, (TA,) and carRa Eayonahu biAlcRaruwri, aor.
carura
, (M, TA,) inf. n. carRN, (K, TA,) He put the medicament called caruwr into his eye. (M, * K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also, (A,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He spread. (A, K.) You say, carRa QllRehu EibaAdahu fiI AlOaroDi (tropical:) God spread his servants, or mankind, upon the earth. (M, * A.) Whence the word curRiyRapN. (M, TA.) ― -b3- And carRati AlOaroDu AlnRabota The ground put forth the plant, or plants. (K.) ＝ -A2- carRa, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) aor.
carura
, [contr. to analogy,] (T, M,) inf. n. curuwrN, (M,) It (a herb, or leguminous plant,) came up, or forth, (IAar, AZ, T, S, K,) from the ground: (AZ, S:) or it (a herb, or leguminous plant, and a horn,) began to come forth; put forth the smallest portion of itself. (A.) ― -b2- carRati AlXRamosu, (T, S, M, K,) aor. curuwrN, inf. n. curuwrN, (S, M,) (tropical:) The sun rose; (S, M, K;) and appeared: (M:) or began to rise: XuruwquhaA is when its light first falls upon the earth and trees: (T, TA:) and carRa qaronu AlXRamos, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) The upper limb of the sun rose: (Msb:) or began to rise. (A, TA.) ＝ -A3- carRa is also syn. with taxadRada [app. as meaning His flesh became contracted, shrunk, or wrinkled]. (K.) ＝ -A4- Also, (T, K,) aor.
carara
, contr. to analogy, (K,) unless carRa be for carira, (MF,) said of a man, The fore part of his head became white, or hoary. (T, K.)

3 caArRato c
3. caArRato, (aor. tucaArRu, S,) inf. n. mucaArRapN and ciraArN, She (a camel) became evil in her disposition. (Fr, S, K.) Hence the saying of Hoteiäh, satirizing Ez-Zibrikán, and praising the family of Shemmás Ibn-Láy,
wakunota kacaAti AlbawRi caArato biOanofihaA
famino caAka tabogiI buEodahu watuhaAjiruho
i. e. [And thou wast like her who has a stuffed skin of a young camel made for her and placed near her that she may incline to it and yield her milk,] that has inclined to the young one of another; [and on that account desires its distance from her, and severs herself from it:] in the S we find, for AlbawRi, AlbaEoli; and for buEodahu, gayorahu; but the former are the correct readings: caArato is a contraction of caArRato: or, accord. to some, it is for caMCarato: see art. cOr. (IB and TA.) ― -b2- One says also, fiI fulaAnK ciraArN, meaning (assumed tropical:) In such a one is aversion, arising from anger, like that of a she-camel: (AZ, S:) or anger and aversion (Th, M, K, TA) and disapprobation. (Th, TA)

R. Q. 1 carocara c
R. Q. 1. carocara: see 1, first sentence.

carRN c
carRN The young ones [or grubs] of ants: (M, A, Msb, K:) accord. to Th, (M, TA,) one hundred of them weigh one barley-corn: (M, K:) or, accord. to En-Neysábooree, [who perhaps held carRN to signify ant's eggs,] seventy of them weigh a gnat's wing, and seventy gnat's wings weigh one grain: (MF:) or the smallest of ants: (S:) or small red ants: (TA:) or it signifies, (TA,) or signifies also, (A,) the motes that are seen in a ray of the sun that enters through an aperture: (A, * TA:) as though they were particles of a thing sprinkled: and in like manner carRaAtu AlcRahabi [minute particles of gold]: (A:) the sing., (S,) or [rather] n. un., (Msb, K,) is carRapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) [of which the pl. is carRaAtN.] [See an ex., from the Kur x. 62, voce mivoqaAlN.] ― -b2- See also curRiyRapN.

caruwrN c
caruwrN A thing sprinkled: (M:) a dry medicament, (T, TA,) such as is sprinkled in the eye, (T, A, K,) and upon a wound, or sore: (T, TA:) or a kind of Uivomid [q. v.]. [Har p. 86.) ― -b2- See also cariyrapN.

curaArapN c
curaArapN What falls about, (M, A, K,) of perfume, when one sprinkles it, (A,) or of caruwr, (K, TA,) or of what is sprinkled. (M, and so accord. to the CK.)

cariyrapN c
cariyrapN (S, A, Msb, K) and caruwrN↓ (S, Msb, K) A kind of perfume, (Msb, K,) the particles of the qaSabu AlTRiybi [or calamus aromaticus, also called qaSabu AlcRariyrapi, q. v., in art. qSb], (T, M, A, Msb,) which is brought from India, (A, Msb,) and resembles the reeds of which arrows are made: (T, A, Msb:) its internodal portions are filled with a white substance like spiders' webs; and when powdered, it is a perfume, inclining to yellowness and whiteness: (Sgh, Msb:) or, as some say, it is a mixed kind of perfume: (TA:) [but this, if correct, seems to be a second application:] pl. of the latter, OacirRapN. (S, K.)

carRiIRN c
carRiIRN a rel. n. from carRN, (T,) (tropical:) The diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, of a sword: (T, M, A, K:) likened to the track of young ants. (M, A.) It occurs in poetry, in which some read durRiIRN [q. v.]. (M.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A sword having much of such wavy marks, &c. (K.)

curRiyRapN c
curRiyRapN, (S, Msb, K,) the most chaste form, (Msb,) and cirRiyRapN, (Msb, K,) and cariyRapN, this last without a sheddeh to the r (Msb,) [respecting the derivation of which see art. crO,] (assumed tropical:) Children, or offspring, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) as also carRN↓, (Msb,) of a man, (S, K,) [and of genii: see art. crO,] male or female: (IAth:) little ones, or young ones. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Progenitors, or ancestors. (Msb, MF.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Women. (Mgh, K.) ― -b4- Used in a sing. as well as a pl. sense. (Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b5- Pl. curRiyRaAtN and (sometimes, Msb) caraAriIRu. (S, Msb, K.) [In the CK, the latter pl., with the article, is written AlcRaraAriI, without a sheddeh to the I. ― -b6- For examples, see art. crO.]

micarRapN c
micarRapN An instrument with which grain is scattered. (K.)

mucaArRN c
mucaArRN A she-camel evil in disposition. (Fr, S, K.) [See 3.]

1 caraOa c
1. caraOa, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
caraAa
, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. caroCN, (S, M, Msb,) He (God) created, syn. xalaqa, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) Alxaloqa [the creation; i. e. the things that are created]. (T, S, M, Msb.) walaqado caraOonaA lijahanRama kaviyrFA mina QlojinRi wa QloUinosi, in the Kur [vii. 178], means [And verily] we have created [for Hell many of the jinn, or genii, and of mankind]. (T.) ― -b2- He multiplied, or made numerous. (K.) yacoraWukumo fiyhi, in the Kur [xlii. 9], means He multiplieth you thereby; i. e., by making of you, and of the cattle, pairs, males and females: so says Zj; and Fr says the like; and this is a correct explanation. (T.) ― -b3- Also, (S, M, K,) and so caraA, (TA,) He sowed land: (S, M, K, TA:) but the latter verb is said to be the more chaste. (MF.) ＝ -A2- caraOa fuwhu His teeth fell out from his mouth; (K, TA;) as also caraA and caraI, without C: (TA:) but the most chaste is said to be without C: caraOa, with C, is said to be of weak authority, or a mispronunciation. (MF.) ― -b2- cariYa, (M, K,) or cariYa XaEarahu, (S,) aor.
caraAa
, (K,) inf. n. caraON; (S, * M, O;) and caraOa, (S, K,) aor.
caraAa
; (K;) and caruWa, aor.
caruAa
; (Ktr, TA;) His hair became white, or hoary, in the fore part of his
head: (S:) or he had whiteness intermixed with blackness in the hair of his head: (M:) or his hair became white, or hoary: (K:) or he began to become white, or hoary, (M, K,) in the fore part of his head, (K,) or in the upper part of each side of the head. (A, TA.) The epithet is OacoraOu↓; fem. caroMCN. (S, M, K. [In some copies of the K, caroOaI is erroneously put for caroMCu.])

4 AcrOhu c
4. AcrOhu He angered him; provoked him to anger. (T, M, K.) ― -b2- AcrOhu biSaAHibihi He incited him against his companion. (AZ, T.) And AcrOhu biAlXRaIoCi He incited him, or urged him, to do, or attempt, the thing. (M, K.) And AcrOhu UilaIkacaA He constrained him, or compelled him, to have recourse to, or to do, such a thing. (K, * TA.) A 'Obeyd mentions OacoraI, without C; but 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh asserts that this is incorrect. (M.) ― -b3- AcrO AldRamoEa He, or it, made tears to flow. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- And AcrOh He frightened him. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- OacoraOato She (a camel) excerned (Oanozalato) the milk (M, K, TA) from [app. a mistake for into] her udder: a dial. var. of OadoraOato [q. v.]. (TA.) The epithet applied to the she-camel so doing is mucoriYN↓. (M, K.)

caroCN c
caroCN The act of creating; inf. n. of caraOa. (S, M, Msb.) ― -b2- [And used in the sense of the pass. part. n. of that verb; and alike as sing. and pl. because originally an inf. n.] caroCu AlnRaAri, (S, K, TA,) [for caroCN lilnRaAri,] related as occurring in a trad. (S, TA) of 'Omar, (TA,) means Created [i. e. destined] for the fire [of Hell]: (S, K, TA:) but as some relate it, the phrase is carowu AlnRaAri, meaning [either “ the children of the fire, ” agreeably with what next follows, or] “ to be scattered in the fire. ” (S, TA.) ― -b3- Also The number of [ones] offspring: one says, OanomaIQllRehu caroOaka May God increase [the number of] thine offspring; as also carowaka. (T.) ＝ -A2- Somewhat; (M, K;) as in the saying, balaganiI caroCN mino xabarK [Somewhat of news, or information, reached me, or came to my knowledge]: (K, TA:) or caroCN mino xayorK [somewhat of good]: (so in some copies of the K and M:) thus crC is written by IAth: in some copies of the K, curoCN, with damm: (TA:) or caroCN here means a little; and carowN is a dial. var. thereof. (M in art. crw.) Also A little of what is said. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A thing intervening as a separation or an obstacle: so in the saying, maA bayonanaA wa bayonahu caroCN [There is not anything intervening &c. between us and him, or it]. (K, * TA.)

caraON c
caraON: see what next follows.

curoOapN c
curoOapN (S, M, K) and caraON↓, (S,) the latter an inf. n. (M, [see 1,]) the former a simple subst., (S,) Whiteness, or hoariness, in the fore part of the head: (S:) or whiteness intermixed with blackness in the hair of the head: (M:) or whiteness, or hoariness, of the hair: (K:) or the beginning of whiteness or hoariness (M, K) in the fore part of the head, (K,) or in the upper part of each side of the head. (A, TA.)

caroMniIRN c
caroMniIRN and caraMniIRN Intensely white salt: (S, M, K:) derived from curoOapN: one should not say OanocaraAniIRN; (S, K;) for this is a vulgarism: some pronounce it with the unpointed d. (TA.)

cariIoCN c
cariIoCN Sown seed. (S, M, K.)

curRiyRapN c
curRiyRapN (T, S, M, Mgh, K) and cirRiyRapN (M, K) and carRiyRapN, (K,) [or cariyRapN, without a sheddeh to the r, accord. to the Msb in art. cr,] always pronounced by the Arabs without C: (S:) accord. to some, (TA,) from AlcRaroCu; (M, TA;) so says Th; (M;) the measure of the first being fuERuwlapN or fuERiylapN; [so that it is originally curRuwCapN or curRiyoYapN;] (TA;) but the C is suppressed because of frequency of usage: (M:) accord. to others, from AlcRarRu, signifying “ the act of scattering; ” because God scattered the crRyRp upon the earth; and the measure is fuEoliyRapN or fuERuwlapN, [if the latter,] the word being originally curRuwrapN, the last r being changed into I, in a manner similar to the case of taqaDRati AlEuqaAbi [in which taqaDRaDat becomes taqaDRayat and then taqaDRat; so that curRuwrapN becomes curRuwyapN and then curRiyRapN]: (TA:) Children, or offspring, (T, S, Mgh, K,) of a man, and used as a sing. also, (Mgh,) or of men and of jinn, or genii: (S, K:) pl. [curRiyRaAtN (see art. cr) and sometimes] caraAriIRu. (S.) Hence, habo liI mino ladunoka curRiyRapF TayRibapF [in the Kur iii. 33, meaning Give me, from Thee, a good offspring]. (Mgh.) And in a trad. of Ibn-'Omar, fajaEalaniI fiI AlcRurRiyRapi means And he put me among the little ones, or young ones. (Mgh.) ― -b2- It is also applied to signify Progenitors: as in the saying, in the Kur [xxxvi. 41], HamalonaA curRiyRatahumo fiI Qlofuloki AlmaXoHuwni [We carried their progenitors in the laden ark]. (T.) ― -b3- And it is used also to signify Women; [because they are the sources of offspring;] (T, Mgh, TA;) like as samaMCN is used to signify “ rain: ” (TA:) as in the saying of 'Omar, HujRuwA biAlcRurRiyRapi [Perform ye the pilgrimage with the women]. (T, Mgh, TA. [See his saying in full, voce riboqN.])

AlcRaAriYu c
AlcRaAriYu an epithet applied to God, The Creator. (T.)

OacoraOu c
OacoraOu; fem. caroMCu: see 1, last sentence. Applied to a ram, Having whiteness in the head; (M, K;) and so the fem. applied to a ewe: (M:) or having the ears variegated, or speckled, with black and white, and the rest black: (K:) or it has this latter meaning when applied to a horse, and to a kid; and so the fem. applied to a female kid, (S, O,) or to a she-goat: (M:) and is not applied to the sheep-kind. (S, O.)

mucoriYN c
mucoriYN: see 4, last sentence.

1 cariba c
1. cariba, aor.
caraba
, inf. n. carabN (M, A, Msb, K) and caraAbapN, (S, * M, A, K,) said of a sword, and a spear-head, (A,) or of a thing (M, Msb) of any kind, (M,) It was, or became, sharp, (S, * M, A, Msb, K,) and cutting, or penetrating: (Msb:) or, said of a sword, and of a spear-head, it signifies [or signifies also] it was steeped in, or imbued with, poison. (A.) ― -b2- cariba lisaAnuhu, aor. as above, [and so the inf. n.], His tongue was, or became, sharp [properly speaking, i. e. sharp in the extremity: (see caribN:) and also tropically, i. e., in a good sense, as meaning (assumed tropical:) chaste, or eloquent; without barbarousness, or vitiousness, or impediment: and in a bad sense, as meaning (assumed tropical:) profuse of speech; or clamorous: bad, or corrupt: foul, unseemly, or obscene]: he cared not what he said. (TA.) [For] carabN (S, M, A, TA) and caraAbapN (S, A, TA) signify Sharpness of the tongue [properly speaking, or, as is said in the A, tropically]: (S, M, A, TA:) and the former, (TA,) or the latter, (Msb,) [or each.] metaphorically, (TA,) (tropical:) chasteness, or eloquence, thereof; (Msb, TA;) without barbarousness, or vitiousness, or impediment; a quality approved: and (tropical:) profuseness, or clamorousness, thereof; a quality disapproved: (TA:) and the former, [or each,] (assumed tropical:) badness, or corruptness, thereof: (M, K:) and the former, (AZ, S, M, K,) or the latter, (Msb,) or each, (A,) (tropical:) foulness, or obscenity, thereof: (AZ, S, M, A, Msb, K:) and the pl. of the former [used as a simple subst.] is OacoraAbN. (AZ, IAar, S, M, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Hadramee Ibn-'Ámir El-Asadee, (TA,)
walaqado Tawayotukumu EalaI bulalaAtikumo
wa Earafotu maA fiykumo mina AlOacoraAbi
(tropical:) [And I have borne with you not withstanding your vices and evil actions, and have known what is in you of foul, or obscene, qualities of the tongue]; (AZ, S:) [or] ElI bulalaAtikumo (IAar, M, TA) means notwithstanding what is in you of annoyance and enmity: (TA:) but accord. to Th, he said, AlOaEoyaAbi, pl. of EayobN. (M, TA.) [Accord. to Z,] fiyhimo OacoraAbN means (tropical:) In them are [qualities that are] causes of evil, corruption, wrong, injury, or the like. (A.) ― -b3- caribato maEidatuhu, (T, S, M, A, Msb,) aor.
caraba
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. carabN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and caraAbapN and curuwbapN, (M, K,) (assumed tropical:) His stomach was, or became, sharp, or keen, by reason of hunger: (M; but only the first of the inf. ns. of the verb in this sense, and not the verb itself, is there mentioned:) [or] (assumed tropical:) his stomach was, or became, in a good, or right, state: (K; but only the inf. ns. of the verb in this sense, and in the next, and not the verb itself, is there mentioned:) and also, (M, K,) (tropical:) his stomach was, or became, in a bad, or corrupt, state: (T, S, M, A, Msb, K:) thus having two contr. significations. (M, K.) ― -b4- cariba AljuroHu, (S, M, A,) inf. n. carabN, (S, M, K,) (tropical:) The wound admitted not of cure: (S, A:) or was, or became, in a bad, or corrupt, state, and wide, (M, K,) and admitted not of cure: (M:) or flowed with Sadiyd [i. e. ichor tinged with blood]. (M, K.) ― -b5- cariba Oanofuhu, inf. n. caraAbapN, (assumed tropical:) His nose dripped; let fall drops. (M.) ＝ -A2- caraba: see 2, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] carabotu fulaAnFA (tropical:) I excited, or provoked, [or exasperated,]
such a one. (A.) And fulaAnN yaDoribu bayonanaA wayacoribu (tropical:) [app. Such a one makes a separation between us, (see Daraba,) and excites discord: yacoribu is perhaps here used for yacorubu, to assimilate it to yaDoribu]. (A.)

2 crRb c
2. crRb, (M, K,) inf. n. tacoriybN, (S,) He sharpened (M, S, K) an iron instrument [such as a sword and a spear-head &c.]; (M;) as also caraba↓, (M, Msb, K,) aor.
caruba
, (M, L, Msb, TA,) accord. to the K
caraba
, but this is without any other authority, and contr. to analogy, as neither its third nor its second letter is a faucial, (TA,) inf. n. carobN; (M, Msb, TA;) and Acrb↓. (KL.) Also, inf. n. as above, He poisoned a sword, i. e. steeped it in poison, and, when it was well steeped, took it forth and sharpened it; and caraba↓, likewise, is allowable. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- The inf. n. also signifies A woman's holding her infant in order that it may satisfy its want [by evacuation, as the words in the explanation (HatRaI yaqoDiIa HaAjatahu) commonly mean, not, as Freytag supposes, by sucking]. (T, K.)

4 Acrb c
4. Acrb: see 2. ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) He became chaste in speech, after having been barbarous therein. (IAar, T in art. rbc, and TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) His life became bad, or corrupt. (IAar, T in art. rbd, and TA.)

carobN c
carobN, (so in the CK and in a MS copy of the K,) or caribN↓, (so accord. to the TA, [which is followed by the TK, and so in my MS copy of the K, but altered from carobN, which I incline to think the right reading,]) A shoemaker's Uizomiyl [a word well known as signifying his knife, with which he cuts the leather, but here explained in the TA as signifying his UiXofaI with which he sews]. (K.)

curobN c
curobN an irreg. pl. of caribN, q. v.

cirobN c
cirobN i. q. gudRapN [i. e. A ganglion; &c.]: (AZ, T:) or so cirobapN↓: and both signify a certain thing that is sometimes in the neck of a human being or of a beast, like a pebble: or the former word signifies a certain disease in the liver, (K, TA,) slow of cure: (TA:) the pl. of the former is cirabN, (K,) or cirabapN, (AZ, T,) or this latter is pl. of cirobapN. (TA.)

carabN c
carabN an inf. n. of cariba [q. v. passim]. (T, S, M, &c.) ― -b2- See also carabayRaA: and see there a pl. or a dual form, in three places. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) An incurable disease: (M, K:) [in the present day applied to diarrhœa; and this is app. meant by what follows:] a disease that attacks the stomach, in consequence of which it does not digest the food; becoming in a bad, or corrupt, state, and not retaining the food. (L.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Rust. (S, K.)

caribN c
caribN Sharp; (T, S, M, K;) applied to anything, (S, M,) as, for instance, a sword, (S,) or a spearhead; and so macoruwbN↓: (T:) or this latter, applied to a spear-head [&c.], signifies sharpened; (S;) as also mucarRabN↓: (T, S:) or caribN (A, TA) and mucarRabN↓ (M, K) and macoruwbN↓, (T, TA,) applied to a sword (T, M, A, K) and a spearhead, (A, TA,) signify [or signify also] poisoned; (A, K;) i. e. steeped in, or imbued with, poison, (T, M, A, TA,) and then sharpened. (T, M, TA.) And sumRN caribN means Sharp poison. (M, A.) A rájiz says, (referring to cattle, TA,)
dabRato EalayohaA caribaAtu AlOanobaAro
meaning [Upon which have crept insects resembling ticks, that produce swellings where they creep,] sharp in stinging. (S.) ― -b2- lisaAnN caribN [properly signifies] A tongue sharp in the extremity. (M, TA.) Tropically, (A,) (tropical:) A sharp tongue; (S, A, TA;) as also macoruwbN↓: (TA:) (assumed tropical:) a chaste, or an eloquent, tongue: (Msb:) [and (assumed tropical:) a profuse, or clamorous, tongue: (see cariba:)] and (assumed tropical:) a foul, or an obscene, tongue. (Msb.) And caribu AllRisaAni (assumed tropical:) Sharp in tongue: (TA:) [(assumed tropical:) profuse, or clamorous, therein; long-tongued: (see cariba:)] (assumed tropical:) bad, or corrupt, in tongue: (Abu-l-'Abbás [Th], TA:) (assumed tropical:) wont to revile; (T;) foul, or obscene, in tongue; (ISh, T, TA;) who cares not what he says. (ISh, TA.) And caribN, alone, (assumed tropical:) Sharptongued: and (tropical:) long-tongued, or clamorous; or foul, or obscene, in tongue: (K, * TA:) and so caribapN, applied to a woman; (AZ, T, S, A, Msb; *) and cirobapN↓: (AZ, T, S, M, K:) this last [is app. a contraction of caribapN, and used by poetic license: it] is applied by a rájiz to his wife, (T, S, *) as meaning (tropical:) bad, or corrupt, and unfaithful to her husband in respect of her faroj; or, accord. to Sh, it means long-tongued; and foul, or obscene, in speech: (T:) and macoruwbN↓ likewise, accord. to Sh, means foul, or obscene, in speech: (TA:) the pl. of caribN is curobN↓, (K,) which is irreg.; (TA;) meaning (assumed tropical:) sharp; (M, K;) and (assumed tropical:) sharp in tongue [&c.]: (K:) and the pl. of cirobapN↓ is cirabN. (T, S, M.) ― -b3- maEidapN caribapN [(assumed tropical:) A stomach sharp, or keen, by reason of hunger: or (assumed tropical:) in a good, or right, state: (see caribato maEidatuhu:) and also, the contr., i. e.] (tropical:) a stomach in a bad, or corrupt, state. (M, TA.) ― -b4- jurHN caribN (tropical:) A wound in a bad, or corrupt, state, and wide, and not admitting of cure: or flowing with Sadiyd [i. e. ichor tinged with blood]. (M, TA.) ― -b5- caribu Alxuluqi (tropical:) A man of a bad, or corrupt, natural disposition. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also carobN.

cirobapN c
cirobapN: see cirobN: ― -b2- and see also caribN, in two places.

AlcRaribap c
AlcRaribap: see what next follows.

carabaI c
carabaI: see what next follows.

carabiIRN c
carabiIRN: see what next follows.

carabayRapN c
carabayRapN: see what next follows.

carabayRaA c
carabayRaA (assumed tropical:) A vice, fault, defect, or the like; as also carabaI↓. (K.) ― -b2- And A calamity, or misfortune; (S, M, K;) from cariba AljuroHu meaning “ the wound admitted not of cure; ” (S;) as also carabRaI↓, (K, TA,) or carabiIRN↓, (so accord. to the CK,) and carabayRapN↓ [or carabiyRapN?]. (TA.) El-Kumeyt says, maAniI biAlcRarabayRaA meaning (assumed tropical:) [He smote me, or afflicted me,,] with calamity, or misfortune: or with evil, or mischief; and discord, or dissension; (T;) as also biAlcRarabayna↓ [in the form of a pl. applied to rational beings, as though denoting personifications], (K, accord. to the TA,) or biAlcRRarabayoni↓ [in the dual form]; (so in the CK and in my MS copy of the K;) which likewise means with calamity, or misfortune. (TA.) And laqiytu minohu AlcRarabayRaA and AlcRaribapa↓ and Alcrbayn↓, [thus this last is written in the TT as from the M,] meaning (assumed tropical:) [I experienced from him, or it,] calamity, or misfortune. (M.) And OuloqiIa bayonahumo AlcRaraba↓ (assumed tropical:) Evil, or mischief, and discord, or dissension, were cast among them, or between them. (T.)

carabRaI c
carabRaI: see the next preceding paragraph.

curaAbN c
curaAbN Poison. (Kr, M, A, K.)

ciroyabN c
ciroyabN A yellow flower: (K:) or yellow, applied to a flower and to other things. (M.)

SuwfN OacorabiIRN c
SuwfN OacorabiIRN Wool of Ádharbeeján or Adharbeeján or Adhrabeeján; for there are different opinions respecting the orthography of this name: (TA:) OacorabiIRN is a rel. n. from AcrbyjAn: (K, TA:) contr. to rule; for by rule it should be OacariIRN or OacoriIRN. (IAth, TA.)

micorabN c
micorabN The tongue: (K:) so called because of its sharpness. (TA.)

mucarRabN c
mucarRabN: see caribN, in two places.

macoruwbN c
macoruwbN: see caribN, in four places.

1 caraHa AlTRaEaAma c
1. caraHa AlTRaEaAma: see 2. ＝ -A2- caraHa AlXRaIoCa fiI AlrRiyHi He winnowed the thing; syn. carRaAhu. (Kr, K.)

2 crRH AlTRaEaAma c
2. crRH AlTRaEaAma, (S, K,) inf. n. tacoriyHN; (S;) and caraHahu↓, aor.
cariHa
; (K;) He put caraAriyH [or cantharides] into the food. (S, K.) ― -b2- crRHh fiI AlmaMCi, inf. n. as above, He put a small quantity of it, namely, saffron, &c., into the water. (S.) ― -b3- And crRH, [or crRH labanahu, (see caraAHN, below,)] He poured water into his milk, in order that it might become much in quantity. (TA.) ― -b4- tacoriyHN also signifies The smearing with clay a new [water-vessel of skin such as is called] UidaAwaAp, in order that its odour may become good. (AA, K. *)

caraHN c
caraHN A certain tree, of which camels' saddles are made. (K, TA.) [Forskål mentions, in his “ Flora Aeg. Ar., ” p. xcvi. a fabrile wood of an uncertain kind, of which spears, or lances, are made, called drH (thus with the unpointed d), brought from the region of San'à.]

curaHN c
curaHN: see curRaAHN.

caraAHN c
caraAHN, applied to milk, i. q. SayaAHN, (AA, K,) i. e. Mixed with water; as also mucarRaHN↓: (TA:) or
the latter, milk, and honey, mixed with a larger quantity of water. (K.)

curaAHN c
curaAHN and Oibuw curaAHK: see curRaAHN.

caruwHN c
caruwHN: see curRaAHN.

cariyHN c
cariyHN [a coll. gen. n.] i. q. hiDaAbN [i. e. Hills; or mountains spreading over the surface of the ground; &c.]: n. un. with p. (S, K.)

cariyHapN c
cariyHapN: see curRaAHN.

OaHomaru cariyHiIRN c
OaHomaru cariyHiIRN Intensely red; (S, A;) i. e. (TA) i. q. OurojuwaAnN. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- UibilN cariyHiyRaAtN A certain race of camels, so called in relation to a stallion named cariyHN. (S, K. *)

curRaHN c
curRaHN: see what next follows.

carRaAHN c
carRaAHN: see what next follows.

curRaAHN c
curRaAHN and curRuwHN↓, (S, A, K,) the latter (respecting which see below) anomalous in form, (TA,) and carRuwHN↓, (K,) agreeably with analogy, (TA,) and cirRayHN↓ (K) and carRaAHN↓ (Fr) and caruwHN↓ and curaAHN↓ (K) and curaHN↓ (IO) and curRaHN↓ (K) and curRuwHapN↓ and cirRayHapN↓ (ISd) and cariyHapN↓ and curonuwHN↓ (K) and caronuwHN↓, accord. to some, (TA,) and curonuwHapN↓ (ISd) and curaHoraHN↓ and curuHoruHN↓, and ↓the second letter [in the latter of these two forms, or in both,] is sometimes doubled by teshdeed, (K,) and sometimes the second r is meksoorah, and the termination p is also added thereto, (ISd,) and Oabuw crHrHK↓ and Abw caroyaAHK↓ and Abw curaAHK↓, and Abw crHrHpa↓ imperfectly decl., (Kr,) [The cantharis, or Spanish fly;] a kind of insect of a red colour, (S, A, K,) spotted, or speckled, with black, which flies, (S, K,) and is of a poisonous nature; (S, K;) a kind of insect larger than the common fly, variegated with red and black and yellow, having a pair of wings with which it flies, and of a deadly poisonous nature: when they desire to allay the heat of its poison, they mix it with lentils, and so mixed it becomes a remedy for him who has been bitten by a mad dog: (IO:) Ibn-Ed-Dahhán the Lexicologist says that the crRwH is a kind of fly variegated with yellow and white; and what is called faroxapu AldRayolami: by certain of the acute physicians it is described as HayawaAnN duwdiIRN, app. meaning a worm-like animal, of the size of the finger, and of a conical shape, the head of which is at the thickest part of it: and IDrst says that it is a flying insect, resembling the zunobuwr [or hornet], and of a deadly poisonous nature. (TA.) It is observed in the S, with reference to curRuwHN, that, in the opinion of Sb, layosa fiI AlkalaAmi fuERawolN biwaAHidapN; meaning, there is not in the language a subst. (as distinguished from an epithet) of the measure fuERawolN; (marg. note in a copy of the S;) or his meaning is, [there is not a word of this measure] with damm alone; (MF;) or with a single dammeh, that is, to the f; but with dammeh to the f and to the E: (IB:) and it is added in the S, that he (Sb) used to say sabRuwHN and qadRuwsN: Sb, however, also mentions the forms subRuwHN and qudRuwsN. (MF.) The pl. is caraAyiHu: (S, K:) in the L, curRaAHN is also said to be a pl.: and Kr mentions caraAriHu; but AHát says that this last is only used in poetry. (TA.) Sb says that the sing. of caraAriyHu is curaHoraHN, (or, in other words, that one of the [insects called] crAryH is [called] crHrH,) which is of the measure fuEaloEalN, and of which the dim. is curayoriHN↓, formed by throwing out the first curyoriHN; [not H, as it would be by rule, making it of the measure curayoHirN, and its curtailed original fuEayoliEN;] for there is not in the language a word of the measure fElE, except fElE, (S,) which is the proper name of a man. (MF.) AHát cites a verse in which HadoradN occurs as pl. of caraAniHu; but the correct reading is crnwH. (MF.)

caraAriHu c
caraAriHu and carRuwHN and curRuwHN: see curRaAHN.

cirRiyHN c
cirRiyHN and cirRiyHapN: see curRaAHN.

curonuwHN c
curonuwHN and caronuwHN and curonuwHapN: see curRaAHN.

Oabuw caroyaAHK c
Oabuw caroyaAHK: see curRaAHN.

curaHoraHN c
curaHoraHN and curuHoruHN and crRHrH and Oabuw crHrHK and Oabuw crHrHpa: see curRaAHN.

curayoriHN c
curayoriHN dim. of curaHoraHN: see curRaAHN.

mucRaraHN c
mucRaraHN: see caraAHN.

TaEaAmN macoruwHN c
TaEaAmN macoruwHN Food into which cantharides (caraAriyH) have been put. (TA.)

1 caroEN c
1. caroEN, [inf. n. of caraEa,] in its primary acceptation, signifies The stretching forth, or extending, the arm, or fore leg: (S, TA:) [or rather, when said of a man, the fore arm; and of a beast, the arm; though the whole arm of a man is generally stretched forth with his fore arm, and the whole fore leg of a beast with his arm: and tacoriyEN↓ and UicoraAEN↓ and tacarRuEN↓ signify the same, as will be shown by explanations of their verbs.] You say, caraEa AlbaEiyru yadahu The camel stretched forth, or extended, his fore leg in going: and AlbaEiyru tcrRE↓ The camel stretched forth, or extended, his arm (ciraAEahu) in his going. (TA.) ― -b2- caraEahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
caraEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. caroEN, (S, Msb,) He measured it with the ciraAEN [or cubit]; (Msb, K;) namely, a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, Msb, K,) &c.: (S:) and caraEahu biciraAEihi he measured it with his crAE. (TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b3- You say of a she-camel, tacoraEu AlfalaApa (assumed tropical:) She goes quickly, or swiftly, over the desert, as though measuring it; as also tucaAriEuhaA↓: and buEodaAlTRariyqi tucaAriEu↓ (tropical:) She stretches forth her fore legs and so traverses the distance of the way. (TA.) ― -b4- caraEa fulaAnFA He strangled, or throttled, such a one from behind him with the fore arm; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) as also crREhu↓: (K:) or the latter, inf. n. tacoriyEN, signifies, simply, he strangled, or throttled, him; (S, L;) but more properly, he put his neck between his fore arm and neck and upper arm, and so strangled, or throttled, him; and lahu crRE↓, also, has both of these significations. (L.) ― -b5- caraEa AlbaEiyra, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He trod upon the arm (crAE) of the camel, [while the latter was lying with his breast upon the ground and his fore legs folded,] in order that a person might mount him. (K.) ＝ -A2- caraEahu AlqaIoCu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (Mgh,) and so the inf. n., (Msb,) Vomit overcame him, and came forth to his mouth before he was aware, (S, * Mgh, Msb, * K, * TA,) and issued from him: (Mgh:) or vomiting came upon him without his intending it. (Mgh.) ＝ -A3- caraEa Einodahu, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) inf. n. as above, (Ibn-'Abbád,) (tropical:) He made intercession with him. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) [Said in the TA to be tropical; I suppose because the stretching forth the arm is a common action of a person interceding.] You say, caraEotu lifulaAnK Einoda AlOamiyri (tropical:) I made intercession for such a one with the prince. (Z, TA.) And cariEa Uilayohi, like fariHa, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) inf. n. caraEN, (TK,) (assumed tropical:) He made intercession to him. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) In the O, cariEa bihi (assumed tropical:) He made intercession [by him]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- cariEa, aor.
caraEa
, He drank from a skin (ziqR) such as is called caAriEN. (K.) ＝ -A5- cariEato rijolaAhu His legs became tired, or fatigued. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A6- caraAEapN [app. an inf. n., of which the verb is caruEa,] The being wide in step, (S, TA,) and light, or active, in pace, or going. (TA.)

2 crRE c
2. crRE, (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. tacoriyEN: (S:) see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also He spread himself out widely, (El-Moheet, L, K,) and stretched forth his fore arms, (El-Moheet, L,) in swimming: (El-Moheet, L, K:) said of a man. (El-Moheet, L.) ― -b3- He (a man) raised his fore arms; and particularly, in announcing good tidings or in warning: (TA:) or he (an announcer of good tidings) made a sign with his arm, or hand. (S, K.) ― -b4- crRE fiI AlmaXoIi He moved about his fore arms in walking, or going along. (S, K.) And crRE fI AlsRaEoIi, (L, TA,) in the O and Moheet and K, erroneously, fIAlsRaqoIi, (TA,) He helped himself with his arms, and moved them about, (O, El-Moheet, L, K,) in walking, or walking quickly, or running. (L.) ― -b5- crRE liI XayoYFA mino xabarihi (tropical:) He acquainted me with somewhat of his tidings, or case; (K, TA;) [as though he stretched forth his arm with his information;] said by one who has asked another respecting his case. (TA.) ― -b6- [And hence, app.,] crRE bikacaA (assumed tropical:) He acknowledged, or confessed, such a thing. (K, TA.) ― -b7- crRE fulaAnFA and crRE lahu: see 1. ― -b8- [Hence, perhaps,] crREhu, inf. n. as above. (assumed tropical:) He killed him; or slew him. (TA.) ― -b9- crRE AlbaEiyra, and crRE lahu, He bound both of the arms of the camel [to the shanks]: (K:) and the latter, he
bound the camel with the redundant part of his nose-rein upon his [the camel's] arm. (K, TA.) [See also tacoriyEN below.] ― -b10- tacoriyEN also signifies The tinging a captive's fore arm with crocus, or with xaluwq, as a sign of slaughter; which was done in the time before Mohammad. (Meyd, cited by Freytag.) ― -b11- [See also the act. and pass. part. ns., below.]

3 mucaAraEapN c
3. mucaAraEapN signifies The selling by measure with the cubit; not by number, and without knowing the measure. (K.) [In the CK, wAljuzAfu is put by mistake for wAljuzAfi.] You say, biEotuhu AlvRawoba mucaAraEapN I sold to him the garment, or piece of cloth, by measure with the cubit. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places. ― -b3- caraAEotuhu, (TA,) inf. n. mucaAraEapN, (K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) I mixed with him in familiar, or social, intercourse; or became intimate with him: or I became copartner with him; or shared with him: syn. xaAlaTotuhu. (K * TA.)

4 AcrE c
4. AcrE, (K,) inf. n. UicoraAEN: (S:) see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- (tropical:) He exceeded the due bounds, or just limits, in speech, or talk; (S, K, TA;) he talked much; (S, TA;) as also tcrRE↓: (S, Msb, * K, TA:) J says, [in the S,] I am of opinion that it has originated from the stretching forth of the fore arm; for he who talks much sometimes does that; and ISd says the like. (TA.) ― -b3- OacoraEa ciraAEayohi mino taHoti AljubRapi and AicRaraEahumaA↓, He put forth, (K, TA,) and extended, (TA,) his fore arms from beneath the jubbeh: (K, TA:) or OacoraEa ciraAEayohi, and AidRaraEahumaA↓, [the latter with the d unpointed,] he drew forth his fore arms from the sleeves of a narrow-sleeved jubbeh: (Mgh:) the latter verb being of the measure AifotaEala; (Mgh, K;) like AicRakara, (TA,) or AidRakara, (Mgh,) from AlcRikoru: (Mgh, TA:) the former accord. to one relation, the latter accord. to another, occurring in a trad. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b4- AcrE also signifies He seized with the fore arm. (K.) ― -b5- maA OacoraEahaA [How long, or large, is she in the fore arm!] is [from AlcRiraAEu, being] of the same [anomalous] class as OaHonaku AlXRaAtayoni [from AlHanaku]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AcrE qayoYahu He (a man) emitted, or ejected, his vomit. (TA.)

5 tacarRaEa
5: see 1; first and second sentences: ― -b2- and see also 4. ― -b3- tacarRuEN also signifies The measuring a thing with the fore arm. (S, K.) [See also 1.] A poet says, (S,) namely Keys Ibn-El-Khateem El-Ansáree, (TA,)
taraI qiSada AlmurRaAni tuloqaI kaOanRahaA
tacarRuEu xiroSaAnK biOayodiIAlXRawaATibi
[Thou seest the fragments of the hard and pliant spears thrown as though they were what is seen in the measuring, with the fore arm, of rods of palm-sticks in the hands of the females who pare them]: (S, TA:) or, accord. to As, tacarRaEa fulaAnN Aljariyda signifies Such a one put the palm-sticks upon his fore arm, and pared them: and xiroSaAnN means, originally, rods of palm-sticks: and XawaATibu is pl. of XaATibapN; meaning a woman who peels the Easiyb, and then throws it to the munaqRiyap, who removes all that is upon it with her knife until she has left it slender, when she throws it back to the XATbp. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, The splitting (taXaqRuq [which is intrans., but I think it is a mistake for taXoqiyq, which is trans.,]) of a thing into several oblong pieces of the measure of the cubit in length. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b5- tacarRaEati AlmaroOapu The woman split palm-leaves to make of them a mat. (IDrd, K.) Thus some explain the saying of Ibn-El-Khateem, quoted above. (TA.) ― -b6- tacarRaEati AlUibilu AlkaraEa The camels came to drink of the rain-water and waded in it with their arms. (K.) ＝ -A2- tcrRE bicariyEapK (tropical:) He obtained, or sought to obtain, access, or intimacy; or he ingratiated himself, or sought to ingratiate himself; by a means of doing so. (S, K, TA.) You say, also, tcrRE Uilayohi (tropical:) He obtained, or sought to obtain, access to him; &c. (TA.)

8 AicRaraEa c
8. AicRaraEa or UidRaraEa: see 4.

10 AstcrE bihi c
10. AstcrE bihi He concealed, or protected, himself by it, (namely a thing, TA,) and made it a cariyEap [q. v.] for him. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

caroEN c
caroEN, in its primary acceptation, has the signification explained in the first sentence of this article. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, it is used in the sense of] (tropical:) Power, or ability; as also ciraAEN↓; (TA;) or a man's reach, or extent of power or ability. (Msb.) And hence the phrases, DaAqa biAlOamori caroEuhu, and ciraAEuhu↓, (K,) and DaAqa biAlOamori caroEFA, (S, Msb, K,) in which the last word is in the accus. case as an explicative, for the original form of the phrase is that first mentioned, (TA,) and sometimes they said ciraAEFA↓, (S, TA,) (tropical:) He was unable to do, or accomplish, the thing, or affair; as though meaning, he stretched forth his arm to it and it did not reach it; (S, TA; *) or these phrases are thus used because he who is short in the fore arm will not reach that which he who is long therein reaches, nor will the power of the former equal that of the latter; therefore they are proverbially applied to him whose power falls short of the attainment, or accomplishment, of an affair: (TA:) or he lacked strength, or power, or ability, to do, or accomplish, the thing, or affair, and found not any way of escape from what was disagreeable therein: (K:) or he was unable to bear, or endure, or undertake, the thing, or affair. (Msb.) You say also, maA liI bihi caroEN, and ciraAEN↓, (tropical:) I have not power, or ability, to do it. (TA.) And kasara celika mino caroEiI (tropical:) That disabled, hindered, prevented, or withheld, me from doing that which I desired. (TA.) And AiqoSido bicaroEika (tropical:) Deal thou gently with thyself; moderate thyself restrain thyself; i. q. AirobaEo EalaI nafosika; (S, TA;) and let not thy soul, or mind, carry thee beyond thy measure or extent [of power or ability]. (TA.) And OaboTarotu fulaAnFA caroEhu (tropical:) I imposed upon such a one more than he was able to do: (S, TA:) but caroEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) the body: and [accord. to IAar] OabaTaraniI caroEiI means (tropical:) He wasted my body, and cut off my means of subsistence. (TA.) [See also art. bTr.] You likewise say, rajulN raHobu AlcRiraAEi↓ [and AlcRaroEi] (tropical:) A man having ample strength, and power, and might in war or fight, courage, valour, or prowess. (TA. [See also raHobN.]) And DaEiyfu AlcRaroEi (tropical:) Impotent. (KL.) ― -b3- And hence, fulaAnN xaAliI AlcRaroEi (tropical:) Such a one has his heart devoid of anxieties, or solicitudes, and griefs; because the heart is sometimes one of the seats of power: or it may mean, agreeably with the original signification of caroEN, such a one is free from the causes of occupation which require the stretching forth of the fore arm and extending of the hand. (Har p. 131.) And rajulN waAsiEN AlcRaroEi, and AlcRiraAEi↓, (tropical:) A man large, or liberal, in disposition. (K.) And kabura fiI caroEiI (assumed tropical:) Its occurrence, or befalling, was of great moment, momentous, grievous, or distressing, to me. (TA.) ― -b4- caroEN also signifies The measure of anything: and naxolapN caroEu rajalK, A palm-tree of the measure of the stature of a man. (TA.)

caraEN c
caraEN A coveting; desiring eagerly; or lusting. (S, K.) [Perhaps an inf. n. of which the verb is cariEa.] ＝ -A2- See also cariyEapN.

cariEN c
cariEN: see cariyEN, in two places. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) That journeys by night and by day. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Longtongued with evil speech. (K.) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) Good in social, or familiar, intercourse. (K, TA.)

curoEapN c
curoEapN: see cariyEapN.

caraAEN c
caraAEN (S, K) and ciraAEN↓ (ISd, K) (assumed tropical:) A woman (S) light, or active, with the hands in spinning: (S, K:) or one who spins much; who has ability to do so. (TA.)

ciraAEN c
ciraAEN, of a man, (Msb,) [The part] from the elbow to the extremities of the fingers; (Mgh, Msb;) the fore arm; syn. saAEidN [q. v.; thus corresponding to the saAq of the leg]: (Lth, K:) and (tropical:) [the space] from the extremity of the elbow to the extremity of the middle finger: (M, Mgh, * K: [in the last of which, the space is plainly shown to be meant, like as the part is shown in the Msb to be meant in the explanation cited above from that work and the Mgh: see also jariybN:]) in both these senses, sometimes masc., (K,) accord. to Kh: (TA:) J says, (TA,) as relating to the arm, it is masc. and fem.; but Sb says that it is fem.: (S, TA:) [Mtr says,] it is fem.: (Mgh:) [Fei says,] the measure so called is in most instances fem.: accord. to ISk, it is fem.; but some of the Arabs make it masc.: Fr says that it is fem.; but that some of [the tribe named] 'Okl make it masc.: As did not know an instance of its being masc.: and Zj says that such an instance is extr.; not choice: (Msb:) the measure thus called, [i. e. the cubit,] (Msb,) the ciraAEN mukasRarap [or cubit which is divided into fractions], (Mgh,) is six qabaDaAt [or fists] (Mgh, Msb) of middling measure; (Msb;) and this is
called ciraAEu AlEamaAmRapi [the cubit of the common people, or the common cubit], because it wants one qaboDap [or fist] of what is called ciraAEu Almaliki [the cubit of the king], namely one of the Kisràs, (Mgh, Msb,) not the last of them, whose crAE was seven qabaDaAt: (Mgh:) [see also miylN: it is also an astronomical measure; and as such, it seems, from several instances in which it is mentioned by Kzw and other writers, to be, probably, by rule, two degrees; nearly the half, or quarter, of the length assigned in different instances to the measure termed rumoHN; but, like the latter, not precise nor uniform in every instance:] the dim. is curiyRaEapN↓, with p because it is fem.; (TA;) or curayoEN↓ [or curayRiEN↓, without p, accord. to those who make it masc.]: (L voce HarobN:) the pl. is OacoruEN and curoEaAnN; (O, Msb, K;) or, accord. to Sb, the former only; (S, Msb;) and Sb adds, they have given it this form of pl. because it is fem.; meaning, that fiEaAlN and fuEaAlN and faEiylN, when fem., have the pl. of the measure OafoEulN. (TA.) In the phrase AlvRawobu saboEN fiI vamaAniyapK [The garment, or piece of cloth, is seven cubits by eight spans], they say sbE because OacoruE is fem., and vmAnyp because OaXobaAr is masc.; (S; [and the like is said in the Mgh;]) and because the length is measured by the crAE, and the breadth by the Xibor. (S in art. vmn.) ciraAEN is also used as an epithet, applied to a masc. n.: thus they say, hecaA vawobN ciraAEN [This is a garment, or piece of cloth, a cubit in length]. (Kh.) You say also, huwa minRiI EalaI Haboli AlcRiraAEi It is prepared, or made ready, on my part: (S:) and huwa laka EalaI Haboli AlcRiraAEi I will pay it to thee in ready money: or it is prepared, or made ready, for thee: the Hbl being a certain vein in the crAE. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence several tropical significations:] see caroEN, in six places: and see also caraAEN. ― -b3- Hence also, (Z, TA,) (tropical:) The instrument with which one measures the length of the crAE [or cubit], (S, Z, O, Mgh, K,) made of a piece of wood, (Mgh,) or whether it be iron or a rod of wood. (O, K.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] (assumed tropical:) A sleeve: as in the phrase vawobN muwaXRaI AlcRiraAEi (assumed tropical:) [a garment, or piece of cloth, variegated, or figured, in the sleeve]: pl. macaAriEu↓, a pl. not agreeing with its sing., like malaAmiHu and maHaAsinu. (TA.) ― -b5- Of the fore legs of bulls or cows, and of sheep or goats, [The arm; i. e.] the part above the kuraAE: and of the fore legs of camels and horses and mules and asses, [likewise the arm; i. e.] the part above the waZiyf: (K:) [also the arm-bone of any of the animals here mentioned:] accord. to Lth, (TA,) of any animal, [but this is by synecdoche, (assumed tropical:) the fore leg;] i. q. yadN; (Msb, TA;) applying to the whole of whatever is called thus: (TA:) [thus, again, corresponding to saAqN; this latter term, in like manner, having a proper and a synecdochical acceptation. Hence the prov.] laA tuToEimi AlEaboda AlkuraAEa fayaTomaEa fiI AlcRiraAEi [Feed not thou the slave with the shank, lest he covet the arm]. (K.) ― -b6- [Hence,] AlcRiraAEu, also called ciraAEu AlOasad (assumed tropical:) Two bright stars, which are one of the Mansions of the Moon: (S:) [there are two asterisms thus called; together, AlcRiraEaAni: one of them is] AlcRiraAEu AlmabosuwTapu, [also called ciraAEu AlOasadi AlmabosuwTapu,] the two bright stars [ α and β ] in the heads of Gemini: (Kzw in his description of Gemini:) [the other is called AlcRiraAEu AlmaqobuwDapu, and] ciraAEu AlOasadi AlmaqobuwDapu, the two bright stars [ α and β ] of Canis Minor: (Kzw in his description of Canis Minor:) [hence it appears that the ancient Arabs, or many of them, extended the figure of Leo (as they did also that of Scorpio) far beyond the limits which we assign to it: the former crAE accord. to those who make AlnRawoCu to signify “ the auroral rising, ” but the latter accord. to those who make it to signify “ the auroral setting, ” is the Seventh Mansion of the Moon: the following descriptions in Kzw's account of the Mansions of the Moon, and in the O and K and TA, are obscure and inaccurate:] AlcRiraAEu is one of the Mansions of the Moon, (O, Kzw, K,) and is called crAE AlAsd AlmqbwDp, (O, Kzw,) or crAE AlAsd AlmbswTp: (K:) the lion has a crAE which is mbswTp and a crAE which is mqbwDp, (O, Kzw, K,) and this is the one next to Syria, (O, K,) or on the left, (Kzw,) and in it the moon has a mansion; the mbswTp being next to El-Yemen, (O, K,) or on the right; (Kzw;) [but this description of their relative positions should be reversed, as is shown by what precedes and by what follows;] each being two stars, between which is the measure of a sawoT [or whip]; (O;) and the latter is higher in the sky, and more extended, than the other, (O, K,) wherefore it is called mbswTp; (O;) and sometimes the moon deviates, and so has a mansion in it: (O, K:) [it is said in the TA that AlcrAE is also a name of one of the asterisms (nujuwm) of AljawozaMC; but this is the same that is called the mbswTp:] it rises [at dawn] on the fourth of tamRuwz [or July O. S.], and sets [at dawn] on the fourth of kaAnuwn AlMxir [or January, O. S.]: (O, Kzw: [and so in the K, except that in this last, it is erroneously said to set in kaAnuwn AlOawRal:]) so says IKt: but Ibráheem El-Harbee says that it rises on the seventh of tmRwz, and sets on the sixth of kAnwn AlMxr. (O, TA.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl; and see also nawoCN, and nakobaMCu.] The rhyming prosaist of the Arabs says, UicaA TalaEati AlcRiraAEo Hasarati AlXRamosu AlqinaAEo waQsotaEolato fiI AlOufuqi AlXRuEaAEo wa taraqoraqa AlsRaraAbu fiI kulRi qaAEo [When the Dhiráa rises at dawn, the sun puts off the veil, and the rays ascend in the horizon, and the mirage flickers, or glistens, in every plain]. (TA.) And the Arabs assert that when there is no rain [at any other season] in the year, the crAE does not break its promise, though it be but a bagoXap [or weak shower of rain]: (Kzw, TA:) [or] its nawoC is approved, and seldom does it break its promise. (Kzw.) ― -b7- ciraAEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain mark made with a hot iron upon the arm (crAE) of a camel: (S, K:) and is a mark of the Benoo-Thaalebeh in El-Yemen, and of some persons of the Benoo-Málik-Ibn-Saad. (K.) ― -b8- Also (tropical:) The fore part of a spear or spear-shaft: (K, TA:) this is called (S, TA) also (TA) ciraAEu AlaEaAmili. (S, TA.)

caruwEN c
caruwEN: see what next follows.

cariyEN c
cariyEN Wide in step, (S, K,) and light, or active, in pace, or going; (K;) applied to a horse, (S, K,) and to a camel; as also caruwEN↓: (K:) and quick: (S, Msb, K:) [and so cariEN↓; for] cariEaAtN↓, (S, O, K,) applied to the legs of a quadruped (qawaAYimN), (S, TA,) signifies quick, (S, K,) wide in step, taking much of the ground: (O, K:) or, as some say, this last word signifies the legs of a beast, (TA,) like macaAriEu↓, (S, K,) pl. of micoraAEN. (K.) It is said of Mohammad, in a trad., kaAna cariyEa AlmaXoIi (assumed tropical:) He was quick, and wide of step, in walking. (TA.) And you say, rajulN cariyEN biAlikitaAbapi (assumed tropical:) A man quick in writing. (TA.) And Oakala OakolFA cariyEFA (assumed tropical:) He ate quickly and much. (TA.) And qatolN cariyEN (assumed tropical:) Quick slaughter. (S.) And mawotN cariyEN (tropical:) Spreading death: (K:) or quick, spreading death, such that the people can hardly, or can in no wise, bury one another. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) An ample thing, affair, or state. (K.) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) An intercessor. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

curayoEN c
curayoEN a dim. of ciraAEN, q. v.

cariyEapN c
cariyEapN A she-camel by which the archer, or the like, conceals himself from the game, (S, K, TA,) walking by her side, and shooting, or casting, when the object puts itself in his power, having first left the she-camel to roam at pleasure with the wild animals in order that they may become familiar with her; (TA;) like dariyoYapN; (S;) as also caraEN↓: (K:) pl. curuEN. (IAar.) ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) Anything that brings one near to a thing; (IAar;) a means of access, nearness, intimacy, ingratiation, attachment, or connexion; syn. wasiylapN; (S, Msb, K, TA;) and sababN; and wuSolapN; (TA;) as also curoEapN↓: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) pl. caraAYiEu. (S, Msb.) You say, fulaAnN cariyEatiI Uilayoka (tropical:) Such a one is my means of access to thee, and of attachment to thee, or connexion with thee. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, [like dariyoYapN,] A ring by aiming at which one learns the art of shooting, or casting [the lance &c.]. (TA.)

curayRiEN c
curayRiEN: dims. of ciraAEN, q. v.

curayRiEapN c
curayRiEapN: dims. of ciraAEN, q. v.

carRaAEN c
carRaAEN A measurer with the ciraAE [or cubit]. (T in art. Obr.) ― -b2- A he-camel that drives the she-camel with his arm and so makes her lie down that he may cover her. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

caAriEN c
caAriEN [so in a copy of the S and of the K and in the TA: in one copy of S and in one of the K, ciraAE: in the CK, carRAE: but the right reading is caAriEN, as is shown by verses in which it occurs, cited in the TA, and by its pl.,] A small [skin of the kind called] ziqR, which is stripped off from the part next to the ciraAE [or arm], (S, K,) and
which is for XaraAb [or wine]; (S;) and micoraEN↓ signifies [the same; or simply] a small ziqR: (TA:) or, as some say, ziqRN caAriEN signifies a zqR that takes much water: (TA:) the pl. is cawaAriEu. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- naAqapN caAraEapN An excellent she-camel. (TA.)

OacoraEu c
OacoraEu [More, and most, light, or active, and quick, with the arms, or hands, or (assumed tropical:) otherwise]. It is said in a trad., xayoru kunRa OacoraEukunRa lilogazoli The best of you females is the most light, or active, of hand, of you, in spinning: or, the most able of you to spin. (TA.) And qataluwhumo OacoraEa qatolK (assumed tropical:) They slew them with the quickest slaughter. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) More, and most, chaste in speech. (K.) You say, huwa OacoraEu minohu (assumed tropical:) He is more chaste of speech than he. (TA.) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) One whose mother is Arabian but not his father; syn. muqorifN: or the son of an Arabian man by an emancipated slavewoman: (K:) the former is the more correct. (TA.) [See also mucarRaEN.]

tacoriyEN c
tacoriyEN The redundant part of the cord with which the arm [of a camel] is bound: [see 2, latter part:] a subst. like [taSodiyrN and] tanobiytN; not an inf. n. (TA.)

micoraEN c
micoraEN: see caAriEN.

mucarRaEN c
mucarRaEN, an epithet applied to an ass, and to a mule, meaning Having what are termed raqomataAni [q. v.] upon his arms. (L.) ― -b2- Hence, (L,) (tropical:) A man (TA) whose mother is more noble than his father: (S, L, K:) as though, (K,) or said to be, (S,) so called because of the raqomataAni upon the arm [or arms] of the mule, for they come to him from the side of the ass; (S, K;) or so called as being likened to the mule, because he has upon his arms rqmtAn like those of the arm of the ass, thereby resembling the ass; and the mother of the mule is more noble than his father. (L.) [See also OacoraEu.] ― -b3- A lion having upon his arms the blood of his prey. (IAar.) ― -b4- [A beast] struck in the uppermost part of his breast so that the blood has flowed upon his arms. (K.) ― -b5- A horse that outstrips: or (originally, TA) that overtakes the wild animal and has his arms smeared by his rider's piercing the latter so as to make the blood flow forth; (K, TA;) this blood upon his arms being the sign of his having outstripped. (TA,) ― -b6- A bull having black spots, or black places, upon his shanks. (S, K.) ― -b7- mucarRaEapN A hyena having stripes upon its arms: (K:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: or applied to the hyena because of blackness on its arms. (TA.)

mucarRiEN c
mucarRiEN Rain that sinks into the earth to the depth of a cubit. (S, K.)

micoraAEN c
micoraAEN sing. of macaAriEN, [which is contr. to rule,] (S, K,) in a sense pointed out below, (S,) or in all the senses explained below, and of macaAriyEN, (K,) which is agreeable to rule. (TA.) ― -b2- macaAriEu signifies The legs of a beast; (S, K;) as also macaAriyEu, and cariEaAtN; see cariyEN; because the beast measures with them the ground: or, as some say, [like the pl. of ciraAEN,] the parts of a beast between the knee and the arm-pit. (TA.) ＝ -A2- macaAriEu also signifies The towns (quraI, S, or bilaAd, K) that are between the cultivated land and the desert; (S, K;) such as El-Kádiseeyeh and El-Ambár; (TA;) in this sense, (S,) as in others, (K,) pl. of micoraAEN; (S, K;) as also macaAriyEu; (K;) syn. with mazaAlifu; (S;) and baraAgiylu: (TA:) El-Hasan El-Basree speaks of the macaAriEu of El-Yemen. (TA.) [Freytag says, without mentioning his authority, that macaAriEu has the same signification with the inhabitants of Nejd as maxaAliyfu with the inhabitants of El-Yemen and mazaAlifu in the region of El-Hijáz: but this is at variance with all that I have found, in respect of the term mxAlyf.] ― -b2- Also Parts, regions, quarters, or tracts, syn. nawaAHK, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) of a land. (Ibn-'Abbád.) ― -b3- And The places of bending of a valley. (Kh.) ― -b4- And Palm-trees that are near to houses or tents. (S, K.)

macaAriEu c
macaAriEu a pl. [contr. to rule] of micoraAEN, q. v.: (S, K:) and of ciraAEN as signifying (assumed tropical:) A sleeve. (TA.) See the last of these words, near the middle of the paragraph.

1 carafa AldRamoEu c
1. carafa AldRamoEu, (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
carifa
, inf. n. carofN (Lth, T, S, K) and curuwfN (Lth, T, K) and carafaAnN (S, K) and cariyfN and tacoraAfN, (K,) The tears flowed. (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K.) And carafato Eayonuhu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
carifa
, inf. n. carofN, (Msb,) His eye shed tears; (Msb;) tears flowed from his eye. (S, K.) And carafato Eayonuhu damoEahaA, (Lth, T,) or carafati AlEayonu damoEahaA (K) or AldRamoEa, (M, Msb,) aor.
carifa
, (M,) inf. n. carofN and carafN and carafaAnN (Lth, T, M) and curuwfN and cariyfN and tacoraAfN, and [ISd says,] I think that Lh has mentioned as an inf. n. curaAfN, but I am not certain of it, (M,) His eye poured forth its tears: (Lth, T:) or the eye made its tears, or the tears, to flow: (M, K:) or let fall tears, or the tears: and carRafatohu↓, inf. n. tacoriyfN signifies the same: (M:) [or the latter has an intensive signification: or] you say, crRf↓ damoEahu, (K,) or dumuwEahu, (T,) inf. n. tacoriyfN and tacoraAfN and tacorifapN, (T, K,) He poured forth his tears. (K.) ― -b2- [See also carofN, and carafaAnN, below.]

2 carRafa
2: see above, in two places. ＝ -A2- crRf Ealayohi, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. tacoriyfN, (S,) He exceeded it; (T, S, M, K;) namely, a hundred [years], (S, K,) or sixty, (T,) or fifty, or some other number. (M.) ― -b2- crRf fiI Hadiyvihi He added, or exaggerated, in his discourse, or narration; as also zlRf. (IDrd and O in art. zlf.) ＝ -A3- crRfhu AlXRaIoCa He made him to know the thing: a poet says,
laOucarRifanoka Almawota Uino lamo tahorubi
i. e. I will assuredly make thee to know death [if thou flee not]: (IAar, M:) or crRfhu Almawota signifies he made him to be at the point of death. (T, K.)

10 Astcrfhu c
10. Astcrfhu He desired its (a thing's) dripping, or flowing. (M.) ― -b2- And Astcrf AlDRaroEu The udder invited one to milk it; and to desire its dripping, or flowing [with milk]. (M.)

carofN c
carofN [app. in the following sense, as well as in others mentioned above, (see 1,) an inf. n., of which the verb is carafa,] A certain running of horses, in which the legs are put together and [then] the fore legs stretched out with the toes near to the ground. (M.)

carafaAnN c
carafaAnN [app. in the following sense, as well as in others mentioned above, (see 1,) an inf. n., of which the verb is carafa,] A weak gait or manner of going. (S, K.)

damoEN cariyfN c
damoEN cariyfN and macoruwfN↓ Tears shed, or made to flow. (T, M, K.)

carRaAfN c
carRaAfN [accord. to Freytag, Largely flowing: but he does not name any authority.] ― -b2- Quick, or swift; and so zarRaAfN. (M.)

cawaArifu c
cawaArifu, applied to tears (cumuwEN), Flowing. (T.) [And] Running waters. (KL.)

macaArifN c
macaArifN i. q. madaAmiEN [The channels of the tears; &c.: see madomaEN]. (T, S, K.)

macoruwfN c
macoruwfN: see cariyfN.

1 caraqa c
1. caraqa, aor.
caruqa
and
cariqa
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. caroqN, (Mgh, Msb,) said of a bird, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) It muted, or dunged; (JK, Mgh, Msb;) [like zaraqa;] as also AcrAq↓, (Zj, JK, Msb, K,) inf. n. UicoraAqN: (JK:) it is also, sometimes, (assumed tropical:) said of a man: (S, * TA:) and the latter is sometimes (tropical:) said of a beast of prey, and [particularly] of a fox. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, mataI tacoruwqN EalaI AlnRaAsi (tropical:) When wilt thou behave in a lightwitted, or foolish, manner towards men? or utter foul, or obscene, language against them? (TA.) And hecaA kalaAmN yacoraqu Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) This is speech, or language, that is deemed foul. (TA.) And laOacoruqanRaka Uino lamo turabRiEo is a phrase meaning a threat. (TA. [But how it should be rendered, unless it be said by a woman to her husband, (see rabRaEa liQmoraOatihi,) and lAcrqnRk be for laOacoruqanRa Ealayoka, I know not.]) ＝ -A2- cariqa AlmaAlu, [in the JK written caraqa, but said in the TA to be like fariH, meaning The cattle suffered from eating the herb called curaq, is] from AlcRuraqu. (JK, TA.)

4 Oacoraqa
4: see the first sentence above. ＝ -A2- Acrqt AlOaroDu The land produced [the herb called] curaq. (S, K.)

5 tacarRaqato c
5. tacarRaqato She applied laban mucarRaq as a collyrium to her eyes; as also AicRaraqato↓, of the measure AifotaEalato: [so accord, to the copies of the K: but] in the “ Nawádir el-Aaráb ” it is said, AcrRqt↓ AlmaroOapu baAlkuHoli signifies the woman applied collyrium to her eyes. (TA.)

8 Uicotaraqa
8: see what next precedes, in two places.

caroqN c
caroqN Dung (JK, S, Mgh) of a bird; (S, Mgh;) as also curaAqN↓: (AZ, TA:) [or] of the bustard (HubaAraI) and the like: (JK:) the former word an inf. n. used as a subst. in this sense. (Mgh.)

curaqN c
curaqN A certain plant, resembling fisofisap; (JK;) a certain herb, (TA,) i. q. HanodaquwqN [the herb lotus, melilot, sweet trefoil, or bird's-foot-trefoil: so in the present day]: (JK, IDrd, S, K:) it has a slight and sweet odour, and grows in [plains such as are called] qiyEaAn, and in places where water collects and stagnates; and sheep, or goats, suffer from eating it, and sometimes become distended in their bellies: (AHn, TA:) n. un. with p. (AHn, JK, TA.)

curaAqN c
curaAqN: see caroqN.

labanN mucarRaqN c
labanN mucarRaqN Milk mixed with water: (AZ, S, K:) [like mucalRaqN.]

1 caratohu AlrRiyHu c
1. caratohu AlrRiyHu, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) aor. tacoruwhu, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. carowN; (S M, Msb, K;) and aor. tacoriyhi, (S, M,) inf. n. caroIN; (S;) and crRthu↓; and Acrthu↓; (M, K;) the last on the authority of IAar, but said in the T to be disallowed in this sense by AHeyth; (TA;) The wind raised it, (T, S, *) or made it to fly, (AHeyth, T, S, * M, K,) and carried it away; (S, * M, Msb, * K;) and dispersed it; (Msb;) namely, a thing, (Msb, K,) or the dust, (T, S, M,) &c. (S, M.) And accord. to IAar, one says, carati AlrRiyHu, and Oacorat↓, [elliptically,] meaning carati AltRuraAba [i. e. The wind raised the dust, or made it to fly, &c.]. (T.) ― -b2- [Hence,] caraA AlrRiwaAyapa carowa AlrRiyHi AlhaXiyma (assumed tropical:) He carried on the relation uninterruptedly and rapidly [like as the wind carries away the dry herbage that is broken in pieces.] (TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, caraA AlnRaAsu AlHinoTapa [The people winnowed the wheat]. (S.) You say, carawotu AlHinoTapa, (IAar, T, M, K, *) aor. OacoruwhaA, inf. n. carowN; (IAar, T;) and carRayotuhaA↓; (M;) I winnowed the wheat: (M, K: *) or AlTRaEaAma carRayotu↓, inf. n. tacoriyapN; (Msb;) and carayotuhu and carawotuhu; (T;) I cleared the wheat from its straw. (Msb.) And carawotuhu, (S, M,) and carayotuhu, but the former is more approved; and carRayotuhu↓; (M;) I made it to fly, and go away; (S, M;) namely, a thing, (S,) or grain, and the like. (M.) AlOakodaAsi tacoriyapu↓ is well known [as meaning The winnowing of the heaps of grain]. (S.) And hence, (S,) carRayotu turaAba AlmaEodini I sought the gold of the dust of the mine [by sifting it or winnowing it]: (S, K:) and AicRarayotuhu↓ signifies the same. (T and S in art. drI. [See a verse cited in the first paragraph of that art.: and see also 2 in the same art.]) ― -b4- carayotu AlXRaIoCa, (T,) or Oacorayotuhu↓, (S, TA,) accord. to AHeyth, (TA,) I threw the thing [or scattered it] like as one throws grain for sowing. (T, S, TA.) And caraA AlOaroDa He sowed the land, scattering the seed; as also caraOa AlArD; but the former is said to be the more chaste. (MF and TA in art. crO.) ― -b5- And caraAhumo, inf. n. carowN, is a dial. var. of caraOahumo, meaning He [God] created them. (M.) ― -b6- caraA AlXRaIoCa He broke the thing (K, TA) without separating. (TA.) And carawotu naAbahu I broke his canine tooth. (M, TA.) ― -b7- caraAhu biAlrRumoHi He displaced, or uprooted, him, or it, with the spear. (Kr, M.) ＝ -A2- caraA, intrans., It (a thing, K, or dust, &c., M) flew up, and went away, or became carried away [by the wind]. (M, K.) ― -b2- He (a gazelle, K, or, accord. to some, any animal, TA) hastened (K, TA) in his running. (TA.) You say, marRa yacoruw, inf. n. carowN, He (a man, S) passed, or went, along quickly: (S, M:) accord. to some, said particularly of a gazelle. (M.) And caraA UilaI fulaAnK He rose and betook himself to such a one. (TA.) ― -b3- It (a thing) fell. (S, K.) ― -b4- caraA naAbahu, inf. n. carowN, His canine tooth broke: or, as some say, fell out. (M.) And caraAfuwhu, (K,) inf. n. carowN, (TA,) His teeth fell out from his mouth; (K TA;) as also caraI, and caraOa; but the last is said to be of weak authority, or a mispronunciation. (MF and TA in art. crO.)

2 1a2RaRa
2: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- [Hence,] carRaI raOosahu, (M, TA,) inf. n. tacoriyapN, (TA,) He combed his head (M, TA) [so as to remove the scurf &c.], like as one winnows a thing: but darRaI [with the unpointed d] is of higher authority. (M.) ＝ -A2- carRayotuhu, namely, a sheep, inf. n. as above, I shore, or sheared, his wool, leaving somewhat thereof upon his back in order that he might be known thereby: and in like manner one says in relation to a camel. (S, M.) [See mucarRFI.] ― -b2- [Hence, app, or from cirawopN, as is indicated in what follows,] (assumed tropical:) I praised him. (IAar, M, K.) You say, fulaAnN yucarRiI fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) Such a one exalts the state, or condition, of such a one; and praises him. (T.) A poet says, [namely, Ru-beh, (so in the margin of one of my copies of the S,)]
EayodFA OucarRiI HasabiI Oano yuXotamaA
(assumed tropical:) [Purposely I praise and exalt what constitutes my grounds of pretension to respect or honour, lest it should be reviled]: (T, S, M:) as though I put it upon the cirowapN [q. v.] (M.)

4 Oa1o2a2a
4: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Accord. to AHeyth, this verb is not used in the sense first explained above; but one says, Oacorayotu AlXRaIoCa Eani AlXRaIoCi, meaning I threw down the thing from the thing: (T, TA:) or UicoraMCN signifies the striking a thing and throwing it down: (Lth, T:) and sometimes, the throwing down without cutting. (M.) You say, Darabotuhu biAlsRayofi faOacorayotu raOosahu [I struck him with the sword and made his head to fall from him]. (T.) And TaEanotuhu faOacorayotuhu Eano farasihi, (T,) or Eano Zahori daAbRatihi, (S,) i. e. [I thrust him, or pierced him, and] threw him down [from his horse, or from the back of his beast]. (T, S.) And Oacorati AldRaAbRapu raAkibahaA The beast threw down its rider. (M.) And AcrI AlXRaIoCa biAlsRayofi He struck the thing with the sword so as to throw it down. (M.) And Oacorati AlEayonu damoEahaA, (S,) or AldRamoEa, (M,) The eye poured forth [or let fall its tears, or the tears]. (S, M.) [See also OacoraOa.] ＝ -A2- AcrI said of a camel, He was, or became, tall, or long, in his cirowap [or hump]. (TA.)

5 tcrRt AlHinoTapu c
5. tcrRt AlHinoTapu The wheat was, or became, winnowed: (M, K:) or was, or became, cleared from its straw. (TA.) ＝ -A2- tcrRI bihi He protected, or sheltered, himself by means of it; (M, Msb;) i. e. by means of a wall, &c., from the wind and the cold; as also bh AstcrI↓. (M.) One says, tacarRa mina AlXRamaAli bacorFI Protect, or shelter, thyself from the north wind by means of a shelter. (T.) And bihecihi AlXRajarapi Aisotacori↓ Shelter thyself by means of this tree: (T:) or biAlXRajarapi Aisotacorayotu↓ I shaded and sheltered myself by means of the tree. (S.) And tcrRti AlUibilu The camels protected, or sheltered, themselves from the cold, one by means of another; or by means of the [trees called] EiDaAh. (M.) And bifulaAnK Aisotacorayotu↓ I sought refuge with such a one, and became in his protection. (S.) And AcrI [thus I find it written, without any syll. signs, evidently for AicRaraI↓, of the measure AifotaEala, like AilotajaOa and AikotanRa,] He sought protection by means of a king. (TA.) ＝ -A3- tcrRI AlsRanaAma, (S,) or AlcRirowapa, (M, K,) He mounted upon [the hump, or the top of the hump &c.]. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tacarRayotu baniI fulaAnK wa tanaSRayotuhumo (assumed tropical:) I married among the cirowap and the naASiyap of the sons of such a one; (As, T, * S;) i. e., among the noble and high of them: (T:) or tcrRI fiyhimo (assumed tropical:) He married among the cirowap of them. (M.)

8 Ui1ota2a2a
8: see 1: ＝ -A2- and see also 5.

10 Uisota1o2a2a
10: see 5, in four places. ― -b2- Aisotacorato, said of a she-goat, She desired the ram; (S, K;) like AisotadarRato. (S.) ― -b3- And the inf. n. AisoticoraMCu signifies The act of leaping upon a female. (KL.)

curapN c
curapN, originally curawN, (S, Msb, K,) or curaIN, (S, M, * Msb,) the p being a substitute (S, Msb) for the final radical letter, (Msb,) [A species of millet; the holcus sorghum of Linn.; thus called in the present day, and also, vulgarly, curap SayofiIR and curapqayoZiIR, to distinguish it from maize, the zea mays of Linn., which is vulgarly called curapXaAmiIR and curap kiyzaAn;] a species of grain; (M;) a certain grain, well known: (S, Msb, K:) the word is used as a n. un. and as a coll. n. (T.) [See miyrapN.]

carowN c
carowN A portion (TarafN) not completed, of a saying; as in the phrase, balaganiI Eanohu carowN mino qawolK [An uncompleted portion of a saying was related to me from him]: (T, S:) or a little; a dial. var. of caroCN [q. v.]. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also, and carFI↓, i. q. curRiyRapN↓, (M, TA,) [respecting the derivation of which there are different opinions, explained in art. crO,] i. e. Created beings: [or children, or offspring: (see art crO:)] or carowN and carFI↓
signify the number of the curRiyRap. (M.) One says, OanomaI QllRehu caroOaka and carowaka, meaning May God increase [the number of] thine offspring. (T.) ― -b2- And carowuAlnRaAri occurs in a trad., as some relate it, instead of caroCu AlnRaAri, as others relate it; meaning [either The children of the fire of Hell, agreeably with what next precedes, or] to be scattered in the fire. (S and TA in art. crO.) ＝ -A3- Also, carowN, The curved extremity of a bow. (So in a copy of the S.)

carFI c
carFI, also written carFA, (or, accord. to some copies of the S, curFI↓,) A thing [such as dust &c.] that the wind has raised, or made to fly, and carried away: (S:) or it signifies what one has winnowed; (M;) or maA tacoruwhu [what thou winnowest, as is indicated by the context of this explanation]; like as nafaDN signifies maAtanofuDuhu. (T.) ― -b2- And carFI or curFI↓ (accord. to different copies of the S) Tears poured forth: (S:) or so cariIRN↓ [or damoEN cariIRN]. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A shelter; (M, TA;) anything by which one is protected, or sheltered: (S, Msb:) a shelter from the cold wind, consisting of a wall, or of trees: and particularly a shelter that is made for camels such as are termed Xawol, by pulling up trees of the kind called Earofaj &c. and placing them one upon another in the direction whence blows the north, or northerly, wind, in the camel's nightly resting-place. (T.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN fiI caraI fulaAnK Such a one is in the protection of such a one. (T.) And OanaA fiI ZilRi fulaAnN wafiI caraAhu I am in the protection of such a one, and in his shelter. (S.) And [hence, perhaps,] UinRa fulaAnFA lakariymu AlcRaraI (assumed tropical:) Verily such a one is generous in disposition. (AZ, T.) ― -b2- Also The court, or yard, (finaMC,) of a house. (Har pp. 56 and 442.) ＝ -A3- see also carowN, in two places.

curFI c
curFI: see carFI, in two places: ― -b2- and curaAwapN.

carowapN c
carowapN Much property; like varowapN: so in the saying, huwa cuw carowapK [He is a possessor of much property]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also cirowapN.

curowapN c
curowapN: see what next follows.

cirowapN c
