mucalRalN: see caliylN. ― -b2- Also, [applied to palmtrees (naxol),] (assumed tropical:) Having the fruit thereof bent [down] in order that it may be [easily] gathered: [see also its verb (2):] so in the following verse of Imra-el-Keys: (Sgh, TA:)
wakaXoHK laTiyfK kaAljadiyli muxaSRarK
wasaAqK kaOunobuwbi AlsRaqiIRi AlmucalRali
meaning And a waist slender like the camel's nose-rein of [twisted] leather, thin; and a shank resembling, in the clearness of its colour, the stalk (lit. internodal portion) of the papyrus (barodiIR) growing among irrigated palm-trees having their racemes bent down (culRilato) by reason of the abundance of their fruit; so that their branches overshade these papyrus-plants: or, accord. to some, and a shank resembling the stalk of the irrigated papyrus that is bent down (mucalRal) by saturation: (EM pp. 28 and 29:) As says that it means, [agreeably with the former explanation,] saAqK kaOunobuwbi barodiIRK bayona hecaA AlnRaxoli AlmucRalali: AO says that saqiIR means watered [naturally,] without occasioning one's taking any trouble to water: IAar explained AlmucalRal as meaning having the way of the water thereto made easy: and some say that by AlsRaqiIR is meant the tender, white, stalk of the barodiIR. (T.)

1 califa c
1. califa, aor.
calafa
, inf. n. calafN, said of a nose, It was short and small: (M, Msb:) or short in the bone, and small in the tip, or lower portion: or calafN is like xanasN [inf. n. of xanisa, q. v.]: (M:) or the verb means it was small, and even in the tip, or lower portion: (S, * K:) or small and slender: or thick and even in the lower extremity; (M, K;) or, as some say, it had in it what resembled a pit, or depression; (M;) not being very thick (layosa bijidRi galiyZK): (M, K: * [in the latter I find layosa biHadRK galiyZK, which I doubt not to be a mistranscription:]) or it was short in the tip, or lower portion, and even in the bone, without prominence. (M.) And said of a man, He had a nose such as is above described. (S, K.)

Oacolafu c
Oacolafu A man having a nose such as is described above: (S, Msb, K:) or having a short and slender nose: (Mgh:) fem. calofaMCu: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. culofN. (S, K.) And A nose such as is described above. (K.) ― -b2- And culofN, applied to sands, (assumed tropical:) Even and compact; as also dukRN. (AHn, M.)

1 caliq c
1. caliq, aor.
calaqa
, (S, K,) inf. n. calaqN, (S,) It (a spear-head [and the like]) was, or became, sharp, cutting, or penetrating. (S, K.) ― -b2- And in like manner, aor. and inf. n. as above, [the inf. n. erroneously written in the CK caloq,] said of the tongue, (tropical:) It was, or became, sharp and eloquent; as also caluqa, aor.
caluqa
, inf. n. calaAqapN; and calaqa, aor.
caluqa
: (K, TA:) and i. q. cariba [which means it was, or became, sharp properly speaking; and also chaste, or eloquent; and profuse of speech, or clamorous]. (S in explanation of the first verb, and app. of the second also, i. e. caluqa, inf. n. calaAqapN; and K in explanation of the first only.) ― -b3- Also, i. e. like fariHa, (assumed tropical:) It (a lamp, or lighted wick,) gave light, shone, was bright, or shone brightly: (K:) [or] so calaqa, inf. n. caloqN. (JK.) ＝ -A2- Also, i. e. caliqa, aor.
calaqa
, inf. n. calaqN, It, or he, was, or became, unsettled, unsteady, unquiet, restless, disquieted, disturbed, agitated, flurried, or in a state of commotion. (S, TA.) You say, caliqotu Eano makaAniI I rose from my place, and became disquieted, or disturbed. (JK.) ― -b2- And, said of the [lizard called] DabR, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) It came forth from the roughness of the sand to the softness of the water. (K.) ― -b3- And caliqa mina AlEaTaXi He (a man) became at the point of death from thirst: (K:) or he became affected severely by thirst so that his tongue protruded. (TA.) ＝ -A3- calaqahu, (JK, K,) aor.
caluqa
, (TA,) inf. n. caloqN, (JK, TA,) He sharpened it; (JK, K;) namely, a knife, (K,) or anything; (JK;) as also Aclqhu↓; (Lth, K;) and clRqh↓, (K,) inf. n. tacoliyqN. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And calaqahu said of the [hot wind called] samuwm, or of fasting, It weakened him, (K,) and emaciated him, and disquieted him, or disturbed him; (TA;) as also Aclqhu↓: (K, TA:) or the latter, thus used, it affected him severely, afflicted him, or distressed him. (JK.) ＝ -A5- calaqa said of a bird, i. q. caraqa [It muted, or dunged]; (K;) and in like manner, caroqahu Aclq↓ (K, * TA) it cast forth its dung quickly. (TA.)

2 clRqhu c
2. clRqhu, inf. n. tacoliyqN: see 1: ＝ -A2- and 4 ＝ -A3- clRq Alfarasa, (JK, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) i. q. DamRarahu [He made the horse lean, or light of flesh; or prepared him for racing, &c. by feeding him with food barely sufficient to sustain him, after he had become fat, or after he had been fed with fodder so that he had become fat; &c.;] (JK, K;) and took good care of him. (JK.)

4 Aclqhu c
4. Aclqhu as syn. with calaqahu and clRqhu: see 1. ― -b2- Also, (inf. n. UicolaAqN, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He made it to give light, shine, become bright, or shine brightly; namely, a lamp, or lighted wick. (JK, K.) ＝ -A2- Also He, or it, unsettled, disquieted, disturbed, agitated, flurried, or put into a state of commotion, him, or it. (JK, S, K.) You say, OataAniI xabarN faOacolaqaniI News came to me, and unsettled me, or disquieted me, &c. (JK.) And it is said in a trad. of Má'iz, lamRaA Oacolaqatohu AlHijaArapu jamaza, (Mgh, TA,) i. e. When the stones disquieted him, &c.: (TA:) or when the stones hit him, or hurt him, with the point, or edge, [or rather the points, or edges,] thereof, he ran [or went] quickly. (Mgh.) See also 1, last sentence but one. You say also, OacolaqaniI qawoluka Thy saying afflicted me, or distressed me, so that I writhed, or showed that I was hurt. (TA.) And Aclq AlDRabRa He poured water into the hole of the [lizard called] DbR in order that he might come forth, (S, K, TA,) thus disturbing him; (TA;) as also clRqhu↓, (K,) inf. n. tacoliyqN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Aclq also signifies He dug OaxaAdiyd [i. e. furrows, trenches, or channels; or rivulets, or streamlets]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And UicolaAqN The casting quickly. (JK, TA.) See 1, last sentence.

7 Anclq c
7. Anclq It (a branch) had [or presented to one (for the verb occurs in a trad. cited as an ex. in the TA followed by liI)] a point, or an extremity, (K, TA,) to be cut off. (TA.)

10 Astclq AlDRabRa c
10. Astclq AlDRabRa He sought, or endeavoured, to make the [lizard called] DbR come forth from its hole. (TA.) One says likewise, AlmaTaru yasotacoliqu AlHaXaraAti The rain draws forth the reptiles, or small creeping things, or makes them to come forth, from their holes; as also ystdlqhA. (TA in art. dlq.) And Astclq AlsRayofa and Astdlqhu He drew forth the sword, or made it to come forth. (TA ibid.)

caloqN c
caloqN (JK, S, Mgh, K) and caloqapN↓ and calafapN↓ (K) and cawolaqN (S, K) The point, extremity, or edge, (JK, S, Mgh, K,) of anything: (JK, S, K:) and the sharpness thereof: (AA, TA:) and the last, [particularly,] the extremity of a spear-head,
and (assumed tropical:) of the tongue. (S, K.) ― -b2- And the first, The slender part of an arrow. (TA.) ― -b3- And The place in which turns the pin, or pivot, of the sheave of a pulley. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- For the first, also, see caliqN, in three places.

calaqN c
calaqN inf. n. of caliqN. (S, K, * TA.) ― -b2- It may be also pl. of caAliqN↓, signifying Sharpened, or pointed, in the iron head or blade: [like mucalRaqN:] ― -b3- and it may be used by poetic license for caloqN. (L.) ― -b4- See also the paragraph next following.

caliqN c
caliqN and Oacolaqu↓, applied to a spear-head [and the like], Sharp, cutting, or penetrating: (S, K:) pl. of the latter culoqN. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And in like manner, both words, applied to the tongue, (tropical:) i. q. caribN [which means Sharp properly speaking; and also chaste, or eloquent; and profuse of speech, or clamorous]: (S, K:) and caliyqN↓ and caloqN↓ and culaqN↓ and culuqN↓, so applied, signify sharp and eloquent. (K.) You say lisAnN caliqN TaliqN, expl. in art. Tlq [q. v.]: (K:) and TaloqN lisaAnN caloqN↓ and TaliyqN caliyqN↓ and TuluqN culuqN↓ and TulaqN culaqN↓: (IAar, S:) and TaloqN caloqN↓ and TalaqN calaqN↓ [or TaliqN caliqN] and TaliyqN caliyqN↓: all meaning [a tongue] sharp, penetrating, or effective: and TuloqN OalosinapN culoqN↓, or TuloqN culoqN. (TA.) And xaTiybN caliqN and caliyqN↓ (S, K) (assumed tropical:) [An orator, or a preacher,] chaste in speech, or eloquent: (K, * TA:) the fem. of each of these epithets is with p. (S, K. *)

culaqN c
culaqN and culuqN: see the next preceding paragraph, each in two places.

caloqapN c
caloqapN and calaqapN: see caloqN.

caliyqN c
caliyqN: see caliqN, in four places. ― -b2- Also A vehement run or running. (JK, TA.)

caAliqN c
caAliqN: see calaqN.

cawolaqN c
cawolaqN: see caloqN.

cawolaqiyRapN c
cawolaqiyRapN: see the paragraph next following, in two places.

Oacolaqu c
Oacolaqu, and its pl. culoqN: see caliqN. ― -b2- AlHuruwfu AlcRuloqu The letters [that are pronounced by means] of the tip of the tongue and the lip: (S, K:) sing. Oacolaqu: they are six; (S;) [comprised in the phrase muro binafolK:] three of these are termed cawolaqiyRapN↓, namely, r and l and n; and three, XafawiyRapN, namely, b and f and m: (S, K:) or all of these six letters are termed cawolaqiyRapN↓. (TA voce EasojadN.) Every quadriliteral-radical or quinqueliteral-radical word [that is genuine Arabic] contains one or two or three of these six letters: every word of either of these classes that does not contain one of these six letters is to be judged adventitious: all the other letters are termed AlHuruwfu AlmuSomatahu. (IJ.)

mucalRaqN c
mucalRaqN Anything sharpened, or pointed, at the extremity: (S:) [like caAliqN:] or a sharp point. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Milk mixed with water: (AZ, K:) [like mucarRaqN:] accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, like nasoCN. (TA.)

micolaAqapN c
micolaAqapN A quick-paced she-camel. (TA.)

celika c
celika: see art cA; and k as a particle of allocution.

1 calaIAlrRuTaba c
1. calaIAlrRuTaba, like saEaI, (K,) [i. e.,] aor.
caAala
, inf. n. caloIN, (TA,) He gathered the fresh ripe dates: (K:) so in the copies of the K; in which is added, faQnocalaI maEahu: but what we find in the Tekmileh is this: ZlR yclI AlrTb AI yjnyh fynclI mEh: and yclI is written as [the aor. of] a quadriliteral [i. e. as the aor. of AclI, for it is without a sheddeh]: (TA:) [here, however, fynclI is evidently, in my opinion, a mistranscription for fayatadalRaI; and the right reading and rendering I therefore hold to be as follows: AlrRuTaba ZalRa yucoliI↓, or perhaps yacolaI, means He continued gathering the fresh ripe dates, they hanging down with him: for the gatherer laying hold upon the raceme, it hangs down with his weight. In the TK, this passage in the TA has been misunderstood and misrepresented, as though it meant that OacolaI maEahu signifies “ he gathered with him. ”]

4 OacoAala
4: see the preceding paragraph.

5 tclRI c
5. tclRI i. q. tclRl [He became lowly, humble, or submissive; or he lowered, humbled, or submitted, himself]: (T, K:) the latter verb is the original: the former being like tZnRI, originally tZnRn. (T.) [See also the next paragraph.]

12 AicolawolaI c
12. AicolawolaI, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. AicoliylaMCN, (S,) He went away hiding himself; stole away secretly. (T, S, M, K.) ― -b2- He hastened, made haste, sped, or went quickly; (TA;) [like AdlwlI;] and (TA) he did so in fear lest a thing should escape him. (T, TA.) And AclwlI facahaba He went back, or away, running quickly. (T.) ― -b3- He was, or became, easy, tractable, submissive, or manageable. (M, K.) [See also 5.] ― -b4- He (a man) was, or became, broken-hearted. (T, K.) ― -b5- It (the cakar) stood in a lax state. (T, K.)

calawolFI c
calawolFI, [in copies of the K calawlaI,] applied to a man, i. q. mucolawolK [part. n. of 12, q. v.]: (K, TA: [in some copies of the K macoluwlN:]) of the measure faEawoEalN; or, as some say, faEaloEalN. (TA.)

riXaMCN mucolawolK c
riXaMCN mucolawolK [A well-rope] unsteady; or moving about, or to and fro, or from side to side. (T.)

1 camRahu c
1. camRahu, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
camuma
, (T, M, Msb,) inf. n. camRN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and macamRapN, (M, K,) He blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended, him, in respect of evil conduct; AlcRamRu signifying AllRawomu (T, Mgh) fiI AlUisaMCapi; (T;) contr. of AlmadoHu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) or of AlHamodu: (Mgh:) and cmRmhu↓, (MA,) inf. n. tacomiymN, (KL,) signifies the same: (MA, KL:) [or this has an intensive meaning: see its pass. part. n., below.] Hence the saying, AifoEalo kacaA wxalaAka camRN, (T, S, K,) i. e. xalaA minoka camRN, meaning [Do thou such a thing, and] thou wilt not be blamed; (ISk, S, K;) or thou wilt have an excuse; [lit.] blame will full from thee: (S in art. xlw:) one should not say xalaAka canobN. (ISk, S in the present art.) cumRa, also, signifies He was satirized, particularly in verse. (IAar, T.) And He was made to suffer loss or diminution [app. in respect of his reputation]. (IAar, T.) ― -b2- camRa AlmakaAnu (tropical:) The place was, or became, affected with drought, or barrenness, and its good things [or produce] became scanty. (TA.) [But perhaps camRa is here a mistranscription for cumRa; for] you say of a land, camRa maroEaAhaA [He dispraised, or discommended, its pasture, when its pasture is scanty]. (S and M and K in art. bcO.) ＝ -A2- camRa, [aor.
camima
,] said of the nose, (S, K,) It flowed [with camiym, i. e. mucus]; (K;) like canRa. (S, K.) And [the aor.] yacimRu is said of camiym; (S, K;) like yacinRu; (S, TA;) meaning It flows. (TA.)

2 camRaRa
2: see 1, first sentence.

3 fulaAnN yucaAmRu EayoXahu c
3. fulaAnN yucaAmRu EayoXahu (assumed tropical:) Such a one passes his life contended with scantiness. (TA.)

4 AcmR c
4. AcmR He (a man) did [or said] that for which he should be blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended; (S;) contr. of OaHomada. (A in art. Hmd.) And Uilayohi AstcmR↓, (M, K,) or UilaI AlnRaAsi, (S,) He did to him, or to the people, that for which he should be blamed, &c. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] OacamRato raAHilatuhu (tropical:) His riding-camel ceased going on; as though she made the people to blame her. (TA.) And OacamRato rikaAbuhumo (tropical:) Their camels upon which they were riding became jaded, and lagged behind, (S, M, K, TA,) not keeping up with the main body of camels; (S, TA;) [as though they made their riders to blame them; or] as though [the idea of] their strength in journeying were derived from camRapN meaning “ a well having little water. ” (TA.) And AcmR biha baEiyruhu (tropical:) [His camel became jaded, and lagged behind with him]. (S, TA.) And OacamRato biAlrRakobi, said of a she-ass, (tropical:) She kept back the company of riders upon camels by her weakness and her ceasing to go on. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A2- AcmRhu He found him, or it, to be such as is blamed, dispraised, &c.; (S, M, K, TA;) contr. of OaHomadahu. (TA.) One says, Oatayotu mawoDiEa kacaA faOacomamotuhu, i. e. [I came to such a place, and] I found it to be such as is discommended. (S) ― -b2- AcRm bihi, (S,) or bihimo, (M, K,) He held him, or them, in little, or light, or mean, estimation, or in contempt: (S, K:) or he left [him or] them blamed, dispraised, &c., among the people. (IAar, M, K.) ＝ -A3- Also, AcmRhu, He protected him; granted him protection, or refuge. (S, K.) ― -b2- And AcmR lahu Ealayohi He took, or obtained, a promise, or an
assurance, of security or safety, and a compact, or covenant, for him, or in his favour, of, or against, him [i. e. another person, making the latter responsible for his (the former's) security, or safety, &c.]. (M, * K, * TA.) ＝ -A4- See also the next paragraph.

5 tcmRm c
5. tcmRm He shunned, or avoided, (T, * Mgh,) or he preserved, or guarded, himself from, (MA,) blame, dispraise, &c.: (T, * MA, Mgh:) this is the proper meaning; and hence, (Mgh,) he felt disdain, or scorn, and shame. (S, MA, Mgh, K, KL.) One says, lawo lamo Oatoruki Alkaciba taOavRumFA latarakotuhu tacamRumaA [If I did not refrain from lying for the purpose of abstaining from sin, I would refrain from it from a feeling of disdain, or scorn, or shame]. (S, K.) And tcmRm minohu [He abstained, or refrained, from it to avoid blame, or through disdain, or scorn, or shame; disdained, or scorned, it; or was ashamed of it]. (K in art. HXm.) And Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà mentions his having heard an Arab of the desert use the expression lA ycmRwn [app. laA yucimRuwna↓, for the A in the measure OafoEala sometimes has a privative property,] meaning They do not shun, or avoid, blame; (laA yatacamRamuwna;) and are not affected with shame. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mino xilaAli AlmakaArimi AltRacamRumu lilSRaAHibi, meaning [Of the properties of generous, or honourable, practices, is] the being regardful of everything that is entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, in the character and appertenances of the companion, or friend, and dispelling from oneself the blame that he would incur from men if he were not regardful thereof. (TA.) And one says, lilojaAri Einodaka tacamRumN and musotacamRN↓ [To the neighbour, with thee, is shown regard of everything that is entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, in his character and appertenances: musotacamRN being app. an inf. n. of AstcmR↓, and this being syn. with tcmRm]. (TA.)

6 tcAmRwA c
6. tcAmRwA They blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended, one another. (M, K.)

10 AstcmR c
10. AstcmR [He required blame, &c.; as though he called for it; or] he was blamed, or dispraised, &c. (KL.) See also 4, second sentence. ― -b2- And see 5, last sentence. ― -b3- [AstcmR bicimaAmihi is used by post-classical writers, and is perhaps a classical phrase, meaning He begged, or implored, his protection. See an instance in “ Abulfedæ Annales, ” vol. iii. p. 170.]

R. Q. 1 camocama c
R. Q. 1. camocama He made his gift small, or scanty. (IAar, T, K.)

camRN c
camRN inf. n. of camRahu. (T, S, M, &c.) [As a simple subst., Blame, dispraise, or censure.] ― -b2- And [the pl.] cumuwmN signifies Vices, faults, defects, or the like. (M, K. [See caAmRN.]) ＝ -A2- See also camiymN. ＝ -A3- And see camRapN.

cimRN c
cimRN: see camiymN. ― -b2- Also Excessively lean or emaciated; and perishing: (K:) or like him who is perishing. (T, TA.) ― -b3- See also cimRapN.

camRapN c
camRapN [as a subst.]; (T, Mgh;) and biYorN camRapN, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) in which the latter word is an epithet, (Mgh,) and cimRapN↓ also, with kesr, (so in one of my copies of the S,) and camiymN↓, and camiymapN; (M, K;) A well containing little water; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) because discommended: (M, Mgh:) and, (M, K,) as some say, (M,) containing much water: thus having two contr. significations: (M, K:) pl. cimaAmN (T, S, M, K) and camRN↓, (T, TA,) [or rather the latter is a coll. gen. n., of which camRapN is the n. un.] A poet says, (S,) namely, Dhu-r-Rummeh, describing camels whose eyes were sunk in their sockets by reason of fatigue, (T,)
EalaI HimoyariyRaAtK kaOanRa EuyuwnahaA
cimaAmu AlrRakaAyaA OanokazatohaA AlmawaAtiHu
[Upon camels of Himyer that were as though their eyes were wells containing little water which the camels employed to draw it had exhausted]. (T, S.)

cimRapN c
cimRapN A compact, a covenant, a contract, a league, a treaty, an engagement, a bond, or an obligation; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) because the breaking thereof necessitates blame: (Mgh:) and a right, or due, (HaqRN,) for the neglect of which one is to be blamed: (Bd in ix. 8:) [an inviolable right or due:] and cimaAmN↓ and macimRapN↓ and macamRapN↓ signify in like manner a compact, a covenant, &c. as above, for the neglect, or nonobservance, of which a man is to be blamed: (Msb:) or these three words [in the CK the first and last only] signify a right, or due; syn. HaqRN: (M, K:) or so the first of them: (T, * S:) and each of them, (M, K,) or the first of them, i. e. cimaAmN, (T, S, Mgh,) i. q. HuromapN [which includes all the significations of cimRapN likewise, those above and those which follow, but appears here to be used as meaning especially a thing that should be sacred, or inviolable; or which one is under an obligation to reverence, respect, or honour, and defend; everything that is entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence. in the character and appertenances of a person]; (S, M, Mgh, K;) every Huromap for the neglect, or non-observance, of which one is to be blamed: (T:) camaAmapN↓, also, and cimaAmapN↓, are syn. with HaqRN and HuromapN: (TA:) and cimRapN signifies also i. q. OamaAnN [as meaning security, or safety; security of life and property; protection, or safeguard; a promise, or an assurance, of security, safety, protection, or safeguard; indemnity; or quarter]; (S, Mgh, Msb, KL, TA;) and so cimaAmN↓: (MA, KL: [explained in both by the Pers. zinohaAro; and in the latter by HuromapN and HaqRN also:]) and responsibility [for the fulfilment of an obligation, for the payment of a sum of money, for the restitution of a thing, or for the safety, or safe-keeping, of a thing or person]; suretiship; (M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also camaAmapN↓ and cimaAmapN↓; (M, K; [in the former of which, these two words are said to be syn. with cimRapN, app. meaning, in all the senses mentioned above;]) and cimRN↓: (M, K: [said in the M to be syn. with cimRapN in the first only of the senses mentioned above in this paragraph: in the CK, wAlcRimRu is erroneously put for wa AlcRimRi:]) the pl. of cimRapN is cimamN (T, Msb) and cimaAmN: (T:) and the pl. of cimaAmN↓ as [a sing.] syn. with [cimRapN and] macamRapN and macimRapN is OacimRapN. (M, K.) Hence, i. e. from cimRapN in the first of the senses explained above, Oahlu AlcRimRapi, (S, Mgh, TA.) and AlcRimRipu, (T, M, * Mgh, K, TA,) with the prefixed noun Ahl suppressed, (TA,) The people with whom a compact, or covenant, &c., has been made; (T, S, M, K, TA;) [and particularly] those, of the believers in a plurality of Gods, [by which are here meant the Christians, Jews, and Sabians, but no others,] who pay the [tax called] jizoyap; (T, TA;) [i. e. the free non-Muslim subjects of a Muslim government, who pay a poll-tax for which the Muslims are responsible for their security and freedom and toleration: see OaholN:] the appellation cimRiIRN↓, (Mgh, Msb,) a rel. n. from AlcRimRapu, (Msb;) is applied to a person of this class; (Mgh, Msb;) because he is rendered secure, or free from fear, for his property and his blood, by means of the jizoyap. (Mgh.) jaEala Eumaru Oahola AlsRawaAdi cimRapF means 'Omar treated [lit. made] the people of the Sawád as those who are termed Oaholu AlcRimRapi. (Mgh.) And OaqobilonaA bicimRapK [or OaqolibonaA?], in the prayer of the traveller, means Restore us to our family in safety. (TA.) It is related in a trad. of 'Alee, that he said, cimRatiI bimaA Oaquwlu rahiynapN wa OanaA bihi zaEiymN, meaning My responsibility is pledged for [the truth of] what I say, and I am answerable for it; (Mgh, TA; *) i. e. this my saying is true, and I am responsible for it. (Mgh.) And it is said in another trad., faqado bariYato minohu AlcRimRap [Then the responsibility of God is clear, or quit, of him]; i. e. there is given to every one, by God, a covenant whereby He binds Himself to preserve and protect him; and when he throws himself into destruction, or does that which is unlawful for him to do, or acts at variance with that which he is commanded to do, the covenant of God fails to aid him. (TA.) fiI cimRatiI kacaA means fI DamaAniI [virtually I am responsible for such a thing; i. e. for paying it, or restoring it, &c.; but lit. in my responsibility is such a thing; or on my responsibility rests, or lies, or be, such a thing; for fI may be here used, as it is in many other instances, in the sense of EalaI]: (Msb:) [or,] in the saying vabata fiI cimRatiI kacaA, [which means Such a thing became, or has become, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, on me,] the term cimRap is applied to designate [the moral sense considered as] the seat [of the sense] of obligation to fulfil what is [properly] termed cimRap [i. e. a compact, or covenant, or the like]. (Mgh.) AlrRaDaAEi maA yucohibu EanRiI macimRapa↓ (T, S, Mgh, *) or AlrRaDaAEi macamRapa↓, (T, Mgh,) meaning [What will put away from me the obligation of] the right, or due, of the woman who has suckled for the sucking? is a question occurring in a trad., (T, S, Mgh, *) as put by a man to the
Prophet: (T:) and the answer was, “ A slave, male or female: ” (T, S, Mgh:) En-Nakha'ee says, (S,) they liked, on the occasion of the weaning of a child, to give the woman who had suckled it something beside the hire: (S, Mgh:) macamRapN↓ in this case is a dial. var. of macimRapN↓: (Mgh:) or, as IAth says, the former is from AlcRamRu; and the latter, from AlcRimRahu. (TA.) You say also, AlrRaDaAEi biXRaIoCK tuEoTiyhi Oacohibo Eanoka macamRa↓ AlZRiYora and AlrRaDaAEi macimRa↓, meaning [Put away from thee the obligation of] the right, or due, that is incumbent on thee to render her for the sucking of thy child [by something that thou shalt give to her who has suckled]. (T.) And Oacohibo Eanoka biXaIoCK macimRatahumo↓ and macamRatahumo↓, (T, and so accord. to different copies of the S and K, in which Enk is omitted,) macamRap being a dial. var., (T,) i. e. [Put away from thee the obligation of their right, or due, by something; meaning] feed them with something, (T,) or give to them something, (S, K,) for they have a right, or due. (T, S, K.) And qaDaI macimRatahu↓ and macamRatahu↓ [He paid his right, or due;] meaning he did good to him, or conferred upon him a benefit or benefits, in order that he might not be blamed. (M, K.) And rajulN cuw macimRapK↓ and macamRapK↓ [in the CK the latter only, A man who has a right, or due,] meaning kalRN EalaI AlnRaAsi (tropical:) [a man who is a burden upon people, to be maintained, or supported, by them]. (M, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also (i. e. cimRapN) A repast, or banquet, to which guests are invited, [simply] for food, or for a wedding. (K.) ＝ -A3- See also camRapN.

cimaAmN c
cimaAmN: see cimRapN, in three places. It is also a pl. of cimRapN [as well as syn. therewith]. (T.)

camiymN c
camiymN Blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) i. q. macomuwmN↓; (T, M, Msb, K;) as also cimRN↓ (T, K, TA) and camRN↓, (M, K, TA,) which last is an inf. n. used as an epithet, and, like [its contr.] HamodN, is applied to a man and to a place of alighting or sojourning or abiding. (TA.) [See mucimRN] ― -b2- See also camRapN. ― -b3- Also, applied to water, Disliked, or disapproved. (S, K. *) ＝ -A2- [As a subst.,] Urine and mucus, (K,) so in the copies of the K, but correctly, (TA,) mucus, and urine (S, TA) that flows from the penis of the goat: (S, K, TA:) or a fluid that flows from the nose. (IAar, T.) ― -b2- And in like manner, Milk [that flows] from the teats of sheep or goats; (K;) or, as in some copies of the S, form the teats of the she-camel; (TA;) or from the teats of the sheep or goat: (so in one of my copies of the S: in the other of those copies omitted:) or milk that becomes sprinkled upon the udders: (Th, M:) or milk that flows upon the thighs and udders of camels and sheep or goats. (M.) ― -b3- Also Dew, (M, K,) absolutely; (TA;) accord. to IDrd: (M:) or dew that falls in the night upon the trees, and upon which dust lights, so that it becomes like bits of clay or mud. (M, K.) ― -b4- And A thing [meaning the sebaceous matter] that comes forth from the pores of the soft part of the nose, like the eggs of ants: (S:) or pimples, or small pustules, (bavorN, T, K,) or a thing resembling bavor, black, or red, (M,) like the eggs of ants, (T, M,) coming forth upon the nose, (T,) or arising upon the faces (M, K) and the noses, (M,) from heat (T, M, K) or from the scab: (M, K:) or the dirty matter that comes forth upon the nose: n. un. with p. (TA.) ― -b5- And Whiteness upon the nose of a kid. (Kr, M, K.)

camaAmapN c
camaAmapN: see cimRapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also Shame, and fear of blame: whence the saying, Oaxacatohu mino SaAHibihi camaAmapN [Shame, and fear of blame, with respect to his companion, seized him]: and OaSaAbatohu minohu camaAmapN, i. e. Shame and disgrace affected him on account of him, or it. (TA.) One says also, OaxacatoniI minohu macamRapN↓ and macimRapN↓, meaning Shame and disgrace by reason of the neglect of that which should be sacred or inviolable, or of that which was entitled to reverence, respect, honour, or defence, or of the obligation or duty, or the right or due, that should be regarded as sacred or inviolable, (mino taroki AlHuromapi,) [seized me on account of him, or it.] (S, K.)

cumaAmapN c
cumaAmapN (assumed tropical:) A remain, remainder, remaining portion, remnant, or relic. (K.) [See also camRaMC, below.]

cimaAmapN c
cimaAmapN: see cimRapN, in two places.

bihi camiymapN c
bihi camiymapN In him is a crippleness, or a chronic disease, (K, [in the CK camAnapN is erroneously put for zamaAnapN,]) or an infirmity arising therefrom or from some evil affection, (M,) that prevents him from going forth. (M, K.)

OaboqaI camRaMCa AlSRubRi c
OaboqaI camRaMCa AlSRubRi (tropical:) [He left] the last remains [of what was poured out, or forth, at once]: so in the A. (TA. [But the last word is there written without any syll. signs.]) [See also cumaAmapN.]

cimRiIRN c
cimRiIRN: see cimRapN, in the former half of the paragraph.

camRaAmN c
camRaAmN One who blames, dispraises, discommends, &c., much, or often. (TA.)

caAmRN c
caAmRN and caAmN, with and without teshdeed, [the latter belonging to art. cym,] A vice, fault, defect, or the like. (As, T.) [See also camRN.]

OacamRu c
OacamRu A horse fatigued, and standing still. (TA.)

macamRN c
macamRN and macimRN: see cimRapN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

mucRimRN c
mucRimRN A thing blamed, dispraised, &c.; [like camiymN;] or made, or caused, to be faulty, or defective, or to have a vice, fault, defect, or the like; (S. K;) as also micamRN↓. (K.) ― -b2- And A man (S) in whom is no motion. (S, K.)

micamRN c
micamRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

macamRapN c
macamRapN, with fet-h only [to the c, A cause of blame, dispraise, discommendation, censure, or reprehension; a blamable, or discommendable, quality or action;] a thing for which one is, or is to be, blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended: contr. of maHomadapN: (S:) [pl. macaAmRN.] You say, Albuxolu macamRapN, (S, K,) i. e. [Niggardliness is] one of the things for which one is, or is to be, blamed, &c. (S.) And UiyRaAka wa AlmacaAmRa [Beware thou of, or avoid thou, or remove thyself far from, causes of blame, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also cimRapN, in six places. ― -b3- And see camaAmapN.

macimRapN c
macimRapN: see cimRapN, in six places. ― -b2- And see also camaAmapN.

mucamRamN c
mucamRamN A man blamed, dispraised, discommended, found fault with, censured, or reprehended, much. (S, K.) ― -b2- And A place held in reverence, respect, or honour. (TA.)

macomuwmN c
macomuwmN: see camiymN, first sentence.

musotacamRN c
musotacamRN: see 5, last sentence.

1 camara c
1. camara, (S,) inf. n. camorN, (K,) He (a lion) roared. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- camarahu, aor.
camura
, (S, M, A,) inf. n. camorN, (T, S, M, K,) He excited, incited, urged, or instigated, him, (T, S, M, A, K, *) with chiding, or reproof, (T, M, A, K, *) and encouraged him, (L,) EalaI AlOamori to do the thing; (A;) as also cmRrhu↓: (L, TA:) and he threatened him; (L, K; *) and was angry with him. (L.) ＝ -A3- camarahu, aor.
camura
; and cmRrhu↓, [inf. n. tacomiyrN;] He felt his mucamRar [q. v.]. (M.) You say also, camara AlrRaAEiI AlsRaliyla The pastor felt the place where the head of the young camel just born was set upon the neck, to know if it were a male or a female: (A:) [or its inf. n., camorN, signifies the same as] tacomiyrN↓ a man's inserting the hand into the vulva of a she-camel, to discover if her fœtus be a male or a female. (S.) [See mucamRirN.]

2 camRara
2: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- tacomiyrN also signifies The determining the quantity, measure, size, or bulk, of a thing; or computing by conjecture the quantity or measure thereof. (K, * TA.)

5 tcmRr c
5. tcmRr, an irreg. quasi-pass. of camarahu, (M,) [or rather a reg. quasi-pass. of camRarahu, which is mentioned in the L, and meaning He excited, incited, urged, or instigated, himself,] as though he blamed himself for a thing that had escaped him: (S:) or he blamed himself (M, K) for a thing that had escaped him: (K:) or he blamed himself for negligence, in order to inspirit himself, that he might not be negligent a second time: (A:) or he blamed himself for the escape, or loss, of [what he was bound to preserve and defend, or] what is termed cimaArN. (TA.) ― -b2- He became angry. (M, K.) ― -b3- He disliked a thing, and was angry in consequence thereof. (Har p. 517.) ― -b4- tcmRr Ealayohi He became changed, or altered, to him, and threatened him with evil. (S, K.) ― -b5- But in the trad. in which it is said of Moses, kaAna yatacamRaru EalaI rabRihi, this expression means that He emboldened himself to his Lord, and raised his voice in his expression of disapproval. (TA.)

6 tcAmrwA c
6. tcAmrwA They excited, incited, urged, or instigated, one another, (S, K,) in war, (S,) or to fight. (K.) ― -b2- Also, sometimes, They blamed one another for neglecting an opportunity. (TA.)

cimorN c
cimorN and camirN↓ and cimirRN↓ and camiyrN↓ A courageous man: (S, * M, K: *) or who combines sagacity, or sagacity and cunning and craftiness, with courage, (M,) or with strength; (T;) and cumaAYirN↓ has also this last signification: (TA:) or the four preceding words signify, (M,) or signify also, (K,) clever, intelligent, and a good assistant: (M, K:) pl. of the first (S, M) and second and fourth, (M,) OacomaArN; (S, M;) and pl. of the third, cimirRuwna. (M.) ― -b2- AlcRimoru and AlcRumaAYiru↓ are also names of Calamities, or misfortunes. (K.)

camirN c
camirN: see the next preceding paragraph.

cimirRN c
cimirRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

camaAri c
camaAri a verbal noun, like nazaAli; [signifying Excite thou, or incite, urge, or instigate, thy companions to the fight: or, perhaps, be thou excited, &c.:] from camarahu fiI AlHarobi. (R.)

camaArN c
camaArN: see the next paragraph.

cimaArN c
cimaArN Whatever one is obliged, or bound, to preserve and guard and defend or protect, (T, M, K, *) and for the loss or neglect of which one must be blamed: (T:) things that are sacred, or inviolable; a man's family, and property (Hawozap), and servants or dependents, and relations: (AA, T:) as also camaArN↓: (TA:) things for which, if he did not defend or protect them, a man would be blamed, and severely reproved: (A:) or what is behind a man, [as a burden upon him,] of those things which it is his duty to defend or protect; for they say HaAmiIAlcRimaAri, [see below,] like as they say HaAmiI AlHaqiyqapi; and those things are termed cmAr because anger (tacamRurN) on their account is incumbent on him to whom they pertain; and they are termed Hqyqp because it is the duty of him to whom they pertain to defend them. (S.) HaAmiIAlcRimaAri signifies The defender, or protector, of those things for which a man is to be blamed, and severely reproved, if he do not defend or protect them: (A:) [or of those things which he is bound to preserve and guard and defend, &c.: see above:] or one who, when he is incited, or instigated, and angry, defends, or protects. (S.) One says also, fulaAnN OamonaEu cimaArFA mino fulaAnK [app., Such a one is a greater defender of those things which it is his duty to defend than such a one]. (S.) ― -b2- yawomu AlcRimaAri The day of war: or of perdition: or of anger. (Et-Towsheeh.)

camiyrN c
camiyrN: see cimorN. ― -b2- Also A man goodly, or beautiful, (K, TA,) in make. (TA.)

camaArapN c
camaArapN Courage: (M, K:) or sagacity, or sagacity and cunning and craftiness, combined with courage [or with strength: see cimorN]: or cleverness, intelligence, and the quality of rendering good assistance. (M.)

cumaAYiru c
cumaAYiru: see cimorN, in two places.

cayomuriIRN c
cayomuriIRN, (K, TA,) with damm to the m, (TA,) [in the CK cayomariIR,] A man sharp in temper, who adheres to things and minds them pertinaciously. (K, * TA.) [And so dayomuriIRN.]

mucamRarN c
mucamRarN The back of the neck: (M, K:) or two bones in the base of the back of the neck: or the part called ciforaI [behind the ear]: or the kaAhil [or upper part of the back, next the neck]: (M:) or this last-mentioned part with the neck and what surrounds it as far as the ciforaI; which is what the mucamRir [q. v.] feels: (As, S:) or the place where the head of a camel is set upon the neck. (A.) ― -b2- balaga AlOamoru AlmucmRaru (tropical:) The affair, or case, or event, reached a distressing pitch; (A, * K;) like balaga AlmuxanRaqa. (A.)

mucamRirN c
mucamRirN A man who inserts his hand into the vulva of a she-camel, to discover if her fœtus be a male or a female: (S, M, K:) because he feels its mucamRar, and thus knows it: he feels its jaw-bones: if they be thick, it is a male; and if thin, a female. (M.) El-Kumeyt says,
waqaAla AlmucamRiru lilnRaAtijiyna
mataI cumRirato qaboliIa AlOarojulu
[And he whose business it was to feel the fœtus, for the purpose of discovering if it were male or female, said to those assisting the she-camels in bringing forth, When, before my time, were the legs felt to discover the sex of the fœtus?]: (S, M:) for it is the head that is felt, as above explained. (M.) The mucamRir is, to camels, as the midwife to human beings. (A.)

1 camala c
1. camala, (S, M, K,) or camalato, (T,) aor.
camula
(T, S, M, K) and
camila
, (S, M, K,) inf. n. camiylN (T, S, M, K) and camolN and cumuwlN and camalaAnN, (M, K,) said of a camel, (T, S,) He, or she, went a gentle pace: (T, M, K:) or went a pace above that which is termed AlEanaqu, (S, M, K,) and above that which is termed AltRazayRudu: [for] A'Obeyd says, when the pace rises a little above that which is termed AlEanaqu, it is termed AltRazayRudu; and when it rises above this, it is termed AlcRamiylu; and then, AlrRasiymu: As says that no camel goes the pace termed AlcRamiyl for a day and a night except the mahoriI. (S.)

2 camRalotuhu c
2. camRalotuhu, inf. n. tacomiylN, I urged him, or made him, (namely, a camel, TA,) to go the pace above mentioned. (K.)

naAqapN camuwlN c
naAqapN camuwlN [A she-camel that is accustomed to go the pace above mentioned]: (M, K:) pl. cumulN, (M, and so in my MS. copy of the K,) or cumolN. (TA: in the CK cumRal.)

camiylapN c
camiylapN Fatigued, or jaded; (IAar, T, K;) applied to a she-camel. (IAar, TA.)

naAqapN caAmilapN c
naAqapN caAmilapN [A she-camel going the pace above mentioned]: pl. cawaAmilu. (T.)

1 camiIa c
1. camiIa, (M, K, and so in some copies of the S,) aor. yacomaI; (K, and some copies of the S;) or camaI, aor. yacomiI; (T, and so in some copies of the S;) or both; (Sgh, TA;) inf. n. camaMCN; (T, * S, M, * K, * TA;) said of a slaughtered animal, (S, TA,) It moved. (T, S, M, Sgh, K, TA.) And camiIa; (M;) or camaI, aor. yacomiI; (K;) inf. n. as above; (M, K; *) He retained remains of the soul, or vital principle: or had strength of heart [remaining: app. said of one dying]. (M, K. [These meaning are there indicated, but not expressed.]) You say, marRa yacomiI, inf. n. as above, He passed by at his last gasp of breath. (Har p. 220.) And camaI, aor. yacomiI, inf. n. camoIN [and app. camaMCN also, as seems to be indicated by what here follows, or perhaps the latter only], He (a sick person) was seized by the agony of death, and was long in suffering the disquietude thereof: whence one says, maA OaTowala camaMCahu [How long is his suffering of the agong and disquietude of death!]. (As, T.) [See camMCN below.] You say also, of a man, camiIa, inf. n. camaMCN, meaning He remained long sick, or diseased. (M.) ＝ -A2- camaI, aor, yacomiI, inf. n. camayaAnN, He hastened, made haste, sped, or went quickly: (Fr, T, S, M, K:) some also mention camiIa, aor. yacomaI, [in this sense, and thus I find in one copy of the S,] but [ISd says,] I am not sure of this. (M.) ＝ -A3- camiIa liI minohu XaIoCN means Somewhat thereof was, or became, prepared for me; or feasible, or practicable, to me: (M:) [and so, app., camaI lI: for] one says, xucR mino fulaAnK maA camaI laka, meaning Take thou, from such a one, what has risen up for thee, or arisen for thee; i. e. maAQrotafaEa laka. (S.) ＝ -A4- camatoniI AlrRiyHu signifies The odour annoyed me, or molested me; (S, M, K;) accord. to AHn: (M:) and took away my breath; referring to a wind emitted from the anus; inf. n. camoIN: (M:) and killed me; (T, M;) accord. to AZ; (T;) aor. tacomiI, (M,) inf. n. camoIN: (TA:) but Aboo-Málik disallows this, and says, you say, camato fiI Oanofihi AlrRiyHu, meaning The odour flew [or rose] into his [nose and] head: and accord. to As, you say, camaI AlHabaXiIRu fiI Oanofi AlrRajuli biSunaAnihi, aor. yacomiI, inf. n. camoIN, The Abyssinian annoyed the man in his nose by the odour of his armpits. (T.) One says also, camaI, aor. yacomiI, meaning He, or it, emitted a displeasing odour. (M.)

4 AcmAhu c
4. AcmAhu He left him ill, or sick, (Oawoqacahu, T, or waqacahu, K, [which latter may mean thus, or he beat him, or struck him, violently, or so that he became at the point of death, &c.,]) and left him at his last gasp. (T, K.) And AcmI ramiyRatahu He failed of hitting the animal at which he shot, or cast, in a vital part, and therefore hastened to kill it: (T.) [or] he hit the animal at which he shot, or cast, and drove it along, and it drove along with him. (M.)

10 AstcmI c
10. AstcmI He sought, or demanded, a thing: (M:) or he sought, sought for, or sought after, repeatedly, or gradually, (S, K,) and took, (S,) a thing that another had. (S, K.)

camFI c
camFI A fetid odour: (M:) an odour that is disliked, hated, or hateful. (K.)

camaMCN c
camaMCN [an inf. n. of 1, (q. v.,) in several senses: as a simple subst., it signifies] Motion [in a slaughtered animal: see 1]: (T, M, K:) and remains of the soul, or vital principle, (S, M, K, and Meyd in explanation of a prov. cited in what follows,) in a slaughtered animal: (S:) or strength of heart: (M, K:) or the state between slaughter and the exit of the soul; but there is no camaMC in the case of a human being: or strong tenaciousness of life after slaughter. (Meyd in explaining the prov. above referred to.) It is said, AlDRabRu OaTowalu XaIoCK camaMCF [The lizard called DbR is the longest thing in retaining the remains of life, &c.]. (T, S.) Hence the prov., OaTowalu camaMCF mina AlDRabRi [Longer in retaining the remains of life, &c., than the DbR]. (Meyd, TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Sickness; as in the saying, fulaAnN baAqiI AlcRamaMCi Such a one is long suffering sickness. (MF.) ― -b3- And A fracture of the head: and a spear-wound, or the like, such as is termed jaAYifN [q. v.]. (Meyd ubi suprà.)

caAmK c
caAmK (M, K) and mucamRaApN↓, (M,) or macomaApN, (K,) An animal shot at, or cast at, which is hit, (M, K,) and which one drives along, and which drives along with one. (M.)

mucamRaApN c
mucamRaApN, or macomaApN: see what next precedes.

1 canRa c
1. canRa, aor. yacnRu, inf. n. caniynN (S, M, K) and cnanu, (K, [but the latter app. belongs to the verb as said of a man,]) It (what is termed caniyn, S, or mucus, TA, or a thing, and likewise the seminal fluid, M,) flowed; (S, M, K, * TA;) [like camRa, aor. yacimRu;] as also cnRn↓, inf. n. taconiynN, (IAar, T, K,) said of what is termed caniyn. (IAar, T.) ― -b2- And canRa said of the nose, It flowed [with what is termed caniyn]; (Lth, T;) like camRa. (S and K in art. cm.) ― -b3- And canRa said of a man, (MA,) or canina, (K, [but this latter I think doubtful,]) see. pers. caninota, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M,) aor. yacanRu, (A'Obeyd, T, S,) inf. n. cananN (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) and caniynN, (K, [but this latter app. belongs to the verb in the senses explained above,]) His nose flowed (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, MA, K *) with what is termed caniyn: (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K: *) and both his nostrils flowed. (M.) ― -b4- cananN also signifies The flowing of the eye with tears. (M.) [You say, app., canRati AlEayonu, meaning The eye flowed with tears] ― -b5- UinRahu layacinRu (tropical:) Verily he is weak and perishing, by reason of extreme old age, or of disease; (S, K, TA;) said of a man: (S:) or yacinRu, (K,) or yacinRu fiI maXoyihi, inf. n. caniynN, (As, T,) means he walks, or goes along, in a weak manner. (As, T, K.) And canRN, as an inf. n. [of canRa], signifies (assumed tropical:) The being in a state of perishing. (KL.) ― -b6- maA zaAla yacinRu fiI tiloka AlHaAjapi HatRaI OanojaHahaA (tropical:) He ceased not to labour, or exert himself, (A, K, TA,) with moderation and gentleness [to attain that object of want until he accomplished it]. (A, TA.) ― -b7- canRa Albarodu, inf. n. caniynN, (assumed tropical:) The cold became intense. (TA.)

2 canRaRa
2: see 1, first sentence.

3 huwa yucaAnRuhu EalaI HaAjapK c
3. huwa yucaAnRuhu EalaI HaAjapK (assumed tropical:) He seeks, or demands, of him an object of want. (S, L, K. *)

4 Oaconana
4: see cunaAnapN, below.

cano c
cano, for UicaAno or UicFA: see UicFA, in art. AcA.

cananN c
cananN [originally an inf. n.: see 1:] Dirt, or filth; and tfl [i. e. tufol or tafol, meaning saliva; or froth, or foam, or the like; or perhaps it is a mistranscription for vufol, meaning sediment, settlings, dregs, or lees, &c.]: mentioned by Suh. (TA.)

cunaAnN c
cunaAnN: see what next follows.

caniynN c
caniynN (Lh, T, S, M, K) and cunaAnN↓ (Lh, S, M, K) [the former originally an inf. n.: see 1:] Mucus (Lh, T, * S, M, K) of any sort, (Lh, M,) or thin mucus, (M, K,) or a thin fluid, (K,) or any fluid, (Lh, M, K,) that flows from the nose. (Lh, T, S, M, K.) ― -b2- And the former signifies also The seminal fluid of a stallion, and of an ass, and of a man, (M, TA,) that flows from the penis by reason of excessive appetence. (TA.)

cunaAnapN c
cunaAnapN A remainder, or remains, of a thing that is weak, or frail, (S, L, K,) and perishing; (S, L; in both of which is added, XayoYFA baEoda XaIoCK yucinRuhaA↓ [app. meaning that leaves it portion after portion, by perishing, or passing away, gradually; but this rendering is purely conjectural, for I have not found the verb here used anywhere explained, nor elsewhere even mentioned];) and particularly of a debt, or of a promise: it is distinguished from cubaAbapN, which signifies a remainder, or remains, of a thing that is sound, or valid, or substantial. (S, L.) ― -b2- Also An object of want; syn. HaAjapN. (K.)

cunaAnaI c
cunaAnaI The mucus of camels: (K:) or [a fluid] like mucus, that falls from the noses of camels: or, accord. to Kr, it is cunaAbaI: [but see this latter word:] or, as is said by some persons in whom confidence is placed, [in the TA, “ in whom confidence is not placed, ”] it is termed zunaAnaI: (M:) or it is a dial var. of zunaAnaI: or it is correctly with c. (K.)

cunayonaMCu c
cunayonaMCu is mentioned by AHn as being in wheat, but not explained by him, except by his likening it to murayoraMC, which is taken forth from wheat and thrown away. (M.) [It is perhaps a mistranscription for cunayobaMCu, q. v.]

cunocunN c
cunocunN, (S, M,) or cinocinN, (T,) The lower, or lowest, part (T, M) of a shirt, (T,) or of a long shirt; a dial. var. of culoculN (M) [or cilocilN]; mentioned by AA: pl. canaAcinu: (T:) the canaAcin of a shirt, (ISk, S,) or of a garment, (K,) are like its calaAcil: (ISk, S, K:) and some say that the n of the former is a substitute for the l of the latter. (TA.)

OacanRN c
OacanRN A man (S, M) whose nose flows with what is termed caniyn: (S, M, K:) and one whose nostrils flow: (T, M:) fem. canRaMCu, (S, M, K,) applied to a woman. (S, M.) ― -b2- It is also applied to a nose; as in the prov., Oanofuka minoka waUino kaAna OacanRa [Thy nose is a part of thee though it be flowing with caniyn]. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (TA,) the fem. signifies also (tropical:) A woman whose menstrual discharge ceases not. (S, M, K.) ― -b4- And qaroHapN canRaMCu (assumed tropical:) [A wound] that will not be stanched. (TA.)

1 canabahu c
1. canabahu, (M, K,) aor.
canuba
(S, M, A, K) and
caniba
, (M, K,) inf. n. canobN; (TK;) and Astcnbhu↓; (M, K;) [properly signifies] He followed his tail, not quitting his track: (M:) [and hence, tropically,] (assumed tropical:) he followed him [in any case], not quitting his track. (K.) You say, canaba AlUibila and AstcnbhA↓ He followed the camels. (A: there mentioned among proper significations.) ElKilábee says,
wajaMCati Alxayolu jamiyEaA taconubuho
[And the horses, or horsemen, came all together, following him]. (S [in which the meaning is indicated by the context; but whether it be proper or tropical in this instance is not shown].) And Ru-beh says,
AlrRawaAHilaA mivolu AlOajiyri Qsotaconaba↓
[Like the hired man,] he was at the tails of the ridden camels. (T, S.) canabati Alqawomu, and [canabati] AlTRariyqu, and AlOamoru [canaba], and AlsaHaAbu yaconubu baEoDuhu baEoDFA, are tropical phrases [meaning (tropical:) The people followed one another, and (tropical:) The road followed on uninterruptedly, and (tropical:) The affair, or case, or event, proceeded by successive steps, uninterruptedly, and (tropical:) The clouds follow one another]. (A.) ― -b2- See also 2.

2 cnRb c
2. cnRb, (T, M, A,) inf. n. taconiybN, (T, A,) said of the locust, It stuck its tail into the ground to lay its eggs: (A:) or, said of the [lizard called] DbR, (Lth, T, M,) and of the locust, (M,) and of the [locust in the stage in which it is termed] faraAX, (Lth, T, M,) and the like, (Lth, T,) it desired to copulate, (Lth, T, M,) or to lay eggs, and therefore stuck its tail into the ground: (M:) or, said of the DabR, it signifies only it struck with its tail a hunter or serpent desiring to catch it: (T:) or, said of the DabR, it signifies also it put forth its tail (M, A) from the nearest part of its hole, having its head within it, as it does in hot weather, (M,) or when an attempt was made to catch it: (A:) [or it put its tail foremost in coming forth from its hole; contr. of raORasa.] ― -b2- canRabati Albusorapu, (T, S, M, K,) or canRaba Albusoru, (As, A, Mgh,) or AlrRuTabu, (Msb,) inf. n. taconiybN, (Msb, K,) (tropical:) [The full-grown unripe date or dates, or the ripening dates,] began to ripen, (Mgh, and so in a copy of the S,) or showed ripening, (Msb,
and so in a copy of the S,) or became speckled by reason of ripening, (As, T, M, K,) or ripened, (A,) at the canab, (As, T, S, M, A, Mgh, K,) i. e. the part next the base and stalk. (Mgh.) The dates in this case are termed taconuwbN↓ (Fr, T, S, M, A, K) in the dial. of Benoo-Asad, (Fr, T,) and tuconuwbN↓ (Fr, T, K) in the dial. of Temeem (Fr, T) and mucanRibN↓; (A, Mgh;) and a single date is termed taconuwbapN↓ (T, M, * K) and mucanRibapN↓. (T, S.) ＝ -A2- cnRb AlDRabRa, [or, probably, canaba↓, being similar to raOasa and janaba and faOada &c., or perhaps both,] He seized the tail of the DbR; said of one endeavouring to catch it. (A.) ― -b2- cnRb AlOafoEaI, said of a DabR, It turned its tail towards the viper, or met the viper tail-foremost, in coming forth from its hole; contr. of raORasa AlOafoEaI. (TA in art. rOs.) ― -b3- cnRb EimaAmatahu (tropical:) [He made a tail to his turban;] (S, K, TA;) i. e. (tropical:) he made a portion of his turban to hang down like a tail: (S, TA:) you say of him who has done this, tacanRaba↓. (S, A, K, TA.) ― -b4- canRabotu kalaAmahu [and kitaAbahu (tropical:) I added an appendix to his discourse and his writing, or book; like cayRalotuhu]. (A, TA.) [Hence, the inf. n. taconiybN is used to signify (assumed tropical:) An appendix; like tacoyiylN.] ― -b5- canRabuwA xuXobaAnahu (assumed tropical:) They made channels for water (which are termed macaAnib) in its rugged ground. (TA from a trad.)

3 caAnabato c
3. caAnabato, (AO, T, K,) written by Sgh, with his own hand, with C, but by others without, (MF,) said of a mare [in parturition], She was in such a state that her fœtus came to her quHoquH [or ischium (here described by MF as the place of meeting of the two hips)], and the siqoI [q. v. (here explained by MF as a skin containing yellow water]) was near to coming forth, (AO, T, K,) and the root of her tail rose, and the part thereof that is bare of hair, and she did not [or could not] lower it. (AO, T.) In this case, she is said to be mucaAnibN↓, (AO, T, K.)

4 Acnb c
4. Acnb He committed a sin, crime, fault, misdemeanour, &c.; (S, * M, * A, * MA, K; *) he became chargeable with a canob [or sin, &c.]: (Msb:) it is an instance, among others, of a verb of which no proper inf. n. has been heard; [canobN being used instead of such, as a quasi-inf. n.;] for UiconaAbN, like UikoraAmN, [though mentioned in the KL, as signifying the committing of a sin or the like, and also in the TK,] has not been heard. (MF.)

5 tcnRb EalaI fulaAnK c
5. tcnRb EalaI fulaAnK He accused such a one of a sin, crime, fault, misdemeanour, or the like, which he had not committed, or though he had not committed any. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 2, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- tacanRabotu AlwaAdiIa (tropical:) I came to the valley from the direction of its canab [q. v.]. (A.) And tcnRb AlTRariyqa (tropical:) He took the road; (K, TA;) as though he took its cinaAbap, or came to it from [the direction of] its canab. (TA.)

10 Astcnbhu c
10. Astcnbhu He found him to be committing [or to have committed] a sin, crime, fault, misdemeanour, or the like: and he attributed, or imputed, to him a sin, &c. (Har p. 450.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in three places. ＝ -A3- Astcnb AlOamoru (assumed tropical:) The affair was, or became, complete, [as though it assumed a tail,] and in a right state. (K, * TA.)

canobN c
canobN A sin, a crime, a fault, a misdemeanour, a misdeed, an unlawful deed, an offence, a transgression, or an act of disobedience; syn. UivomN, (T, M, A, Msb,) or juromN, (S,) or both, (TA,) and maEoSiyapN: (T, TA:) or it differs from UivomN in being either intentional or committed through inadvertence; whereas the Avm is peculiarly intentional: (Kull p. 13:) or a thing that precludes one from [the favour of] God: or a thing for which he is blamable who does it intentionally: (KT:) pl. cunuwbN (M, Msb, K) and pl. pl. cunuwbaAtN. (M, K.) walahumo EalaIRa canobN [in the Kur xxvi. 13, said by Moses, meaning And they have a crime to charge against me,] refers to the speaker's slaughter of him whom he struck, who was of the family of Pharaoh. (M.)

canabN c
canabN and cunaAbaI↓ (T, S, M, A, Msb, K) and dinibRaI↓ and cunubRaI↓ (El-Hejeree, M, K) signify the same; (T, S, M, &c.;) i. e. The tail; syn. cayolN: (TA: [in the CK, AlcRinobiIRu is erroneously put for AlcRinobiIRa:]) but accord. to Fr, one uses the first of these words in relation to the horse, and the second in relation to the bird: (T:) or the first is used in relation to the horse (S, A) and the ass [and the like] (S) more commonly than the second; (S, A; *) and the second is used in relation to a bird (S, M, A, Msb) more commonly than the first, (S, M, *) or more chastely: (M, * Msb:) or the second is [properly] of a winged creature; and the first is of any other; but the second is sometimes, metaphorically, of the horse: (Er-Riyáshee, TA:) or, as some say, the second signifies the place of growth of the canab [or tail]: (M:) the pl. of canabN is OaconaAbN. (S, M, A, Msb, K.) [Hence the following phrases &c.] ― -b2- rakiba canaba AlbaEiyri [lit. He rode on the tail of the camel, meaning] (tropical:) he was content with a deficient lot. (T, A, K.) ― -b3- Daraba bicanibihi [lit. He smote the earth with his tail, AlOaroDa being understood, meaning] (assumed tropical:) he (a man) stayed, or abode, and remained fixed. (K.) [See also another explanation of this phrase below.] And OaqaAma biOaroDinaA wa garaza canabahu, meaning (tropical:) [He stayed, or abode, in our land, and remained fixed, or] did not quit it; [lit., and stuck his tail into the ground;] originally said of the locust. (A, TA. [See art. grz.]) ― -b4- bayoniI wa bayonahu canbu AlDRabRi [lit. Between me and him is the tail of the DbR,] means (tropical:) between me and him is opposition or competition [as when two persons are endeavouring to seize the tail of the DbR]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- AisotaroxaI cnabu AlXRayoxi (tropical:) The old man's XaIoC became lax, or languid. (Á, TA.) ― -b6- rakiba canaba AlrRiyHi [lit. He rode upon the tail of the wind,] means (tropical:) he outwent, or outstripped, and was not reached, or overtaken. (T, A, K.) ― -b7- walRaI xamosiyna canabA Original text has missing initial characters in the last word: the ذَنَ have been added. [lit. He turned his tail upon the fifty,] means (tropical:) he passed the [age of] fifty [years]: (M, TA:) and so walatohu Alxamosuwna canabahaA [lit. the fifty turned their tail upon him]: (A, TA:) the former accord. to Yaakoob: accord. to IAar, El-Kilábee, being asked his age, said, qado walRato liIa Alxamosuwna canabahaA [lit. The fifty have turned their tail to me]. (M, TA.) ― -b8- AitRabaEa canaba OamorK mudobirK [lit. He followed the tail of an event retreating,] means (tropical:) he regretted an event that had passed. (T, A, * TA. *) ― -b9- [The canab of a man is (assumed tropical:) The part corresponding to the tail: and hence,] rajulN waqaAHu AlcRanabi (assumed tropical:) [A man hard in the caudal extremity;] meaning (assumed tropical:) a man very patient in enduring riding. (IAar, M, and K in art. wqH.) ― -b10- [And of a garment, The skirt:] you say, taEalRaqotu biOaconaAbihi (tropical:) [I clung to his skirts]. (A.) ― -b11- The canaba of a ship or boat is (assumed tropical:) The rudder. (Lth and S * and L in art. skn. [See also xayozuraAnN.]) ― -b12- canabN also signifies [(assumed tropical:) Anything resembling a tail. ― -b13- Hence,] (assumed tropical:) The extremity of a whip. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b14- And, of an unripe date, (M, Mgh,) and of any date, (M,) (assumed tropical:) The kinder part; (M;) the part next the base and stalk. (Mgh.) ― -b15- (tropical:) And (tropical:) The outer extremity of the eye, next the temple; as also cinaAbN↓ and cinaAbapN↓ (M, A) and cunaAbapN↓ (A) [and cunaAbaI↓, as used in the K voce AizodajRa, in art. zj]. ― -b16- See also canuwbN, third sentence. ― -b17- Also (assumed tropical:) The end; or last, or latter, part; of anything: pl. cinaAbN (T) [and OaconaAbN]: and cinaAbN↓ [as a sing.], (K,) or cunaAbN↓, (so in the TT as from the M,) has this meaning. (M, K.) You say, kaAna celika fiI canabi AldRahori (assumed tropical:) That was in the end of the time [past]. (M.) And canabu AlwaAdiI and AlcunaAbapu↓: both signify the same [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The end of the valley]: (A 'Obeyd, M, TA:) or cunaAbapN↓ and cinaAbapN↓ and canabapN↓ signify the (tropical:) last, or latter, parts, (K, TA,) in some copies of the K, the last, or latter, part, (TA, [and so in the TT as from the M, and this meaning seems to be indicated in the A,]) of a valley, (A, K, TA,) and of a river, (A, TA,) and of time; (K, TA;) [and cinaAbN↓ app. has the former of these two significations in relation to a valley, accord. to Az; for he says,] it seems that cinaAbN and cinaAbapN↓ in relation to a valley are pls. of canabN, like as jimaAlN and jimaAlapN are pls. of jamalN: (T:) or cinaAbapN↓ and canabapN↓, (S, Msb,) the former of which is more common than the latter, (Th, S, Msb,) signify (assumed tropical:) the place to which finally comes the torrent of a valley: (S, Msb:) the pl. of cinaAbapN↓ is canaAYibu: (T:) the canab of a valley and its miconaba↓ are the same; [i. e. (assumed tropical:) the lowest, or lower, part thereof;] (T;) [for the pls.] OaconaAbN (T, TA) and macaAnibu (TA) signify (assumed tropical:) the lowest, or lower, parts of valleys: (T, TA:) and OaconaAbN signifies [in like manner] (assumed tropical:) the last, or latter, parts, of [water-courses such as are termed] tilaAE. (T, TA. See also miconabN.) It is said in a trad, laA yamonaEu fulaAnN canaba taloEapK [(assumed tropical:) Such a one will not impede the last part of a water-course]; applied to the abject, weak, and contemptible. (T.) And OaconaAbu OumuwrK means (tropical:) The last, or latter, parts of affairs or events. (M.) You say also, HadiyvN Tawiylu AlcRanabi (tropical:) [A long-tailed story;] a
story that hardly, or never, comes to an end. (M.) And yawomN Tawiylu AlcRanabi (assumed tropical:) A day of which the evil does not come to an end: (TA:) and yawomN canuwbN↓ has this meaning; (T, M, TA;) as though it were long in the tail; (M;) or means (assumed tropical:) a day of long-continued evil. (K.) And AitRabaEa Alqawomi cinaAbapa↓, and AlUibili, (tropical:) He followed [the last of] the people, and the camels, not quitting their track. (A.) ― -b18- Also (tropical:) The followers, or dependants, of a man: (T, TA:) and caAnibN↓ and cunaAbapN↓ (assumed tropical:) a [single] follower, or dependant: (S, K:) and OaconaAbN (M, A, K) and cunaAbaI↓ (S) and danaAYibu [pl. of cunaAbapN↓] (A) and cunubaAtN↓, (so in the TT as from the M,) or canabaAtN↓, (K,) but some state that this last is not said of men, (Ham p. 249,) (tropical:) followers, or dependants, (S, M, A, K,) of a people or party; (M, K;) and the lower, or lowest, sort, or the rabble, or refuse, thereof; (M, A, K;) and such as are below the chiefs. (TA.) Daraba yaEosuwbu AldRiyni bicanabihi, in a trad. of 'Alee, means, [accord. to some, (assumed tropical:) The leader of the religion] shall go away through the land with followers, or dependants, (T, * TA,) and those holding his opinions. (T. [But see arts. Drb and Esb.]) And EuqayolN TawiylapN AlcRanabi, a phrase mentioned by IAar, but not explained by him, app. means (assumed tropical:) [The tribe of] 'Okeyl have numerous horsemen. (M.) ― -b19- [Also canabN (as will be shown by the use of its pl. in the verse here following) and] cinaAbN↓, (S, K, TA,) or cunaAbN↓, (so in the TT as from the M,) (assumed tropical:) The sequel, consequence, or result, syn. EaqibN, of anything. (S, M, K.) A poet says,
taEalRaqota mino OaconaAbi lawRK balayotaniI
walayota kalawRK xayobapN layosa yanofaEu
[From considering what might be the sequels of “ if, ” (i. e. of the word lawo,) Thou clungest to the reflection “ Would that I had done so and so: ” but “ would that, ” like “ if, ” is disappointment: it does not profit]. (TA.) And one says, mano laka lawRK bicinaAbi↓ i. e. [Who will be responsible to thee for] the sequel [of the word lawo]? (TA:) [or, as in the Proverbs of El-Meydánee, lawRK bicunaAbapi↓, which means the same.] ― -b20- canabu AlsRiroHaAni: see art. srH. ― -b21- canabu Alfarasi (assumed tropical:) A certain asterism (najomN, M, K, TA) in the sky, (TA,) resembling the canab [or tail] of the horse. (M, K.) [AlcRanabu is a name applied to each of several stars or asterisms: as (assumed tropical:) The star a of Cygnus; also called canabu AldRajaAjapi, and AlrRidofu: and (assumed tropical:) The star beta of Leo; also called canabu AlOasadi. And AlrRaOosu waAlcRanabu signifies (assumed tropical:) The two nodes of a planet: see tinRiynN.] ― -b22- canabu Alxayoli, (K,) or OaconaAbu Alxayoli, (M,) (assumed tropical:) A certain herb, (M, K,) of which the expressed juice concretes: so called by way of comparison [to horses' tails: the latter name is now applied to the equisetum, or horse-tail]. (M.) [Accord. to Forskål, (Flora Aegypt. Arab., p. cxii.,) the Portulaca oleracea (or garden-purslane) is called in some parts of El-Yemen canabu Alfarasi.] canabu AlvRaEolabi (assumed tropical:) A certain plant, resembling the canab [or tail] of the fox; (M, K;) a name applied by some of the Arabs to the canabaAn [q. v.] (T.) ― -b23- [canabu AlsRabuEi (assumed tropical:) Cauda leonis, i. e. circium (or cirsium): (Golius, from Diosc. iv. 119:) now applied to the common creeping way-thistle. ― -b24- canabu AlfaOorapi (assumed tropical:) Cauda muris, i. e. plantago. (Golius, from Ibn-Beytár.) ― -b25- canaba Alvawori (assumed tropical:) A species of aristida, supposed by Forskål (Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. civ,) to be the aristida adscensionis. ― -b26- canabu AlEaqorabi (assumed tropical:) Scorpioides, or scorpion-grass: so called in the present day.]

canabapN c
canabapN, and its pl. canabaAtN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

cunubaAtN c
cunubaAtN: see canabN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

canabaAnN c
canabaAnN A certain plant, (T, S,) well known, called by some of the Arabs canabu AlvRaEolabi: (T:) a certain plant having long branches, somewhat dust-coloured (M, TA) in its leaves, growing in plain, or soft, land, upon the ground, not rising high, approved as pasture, (TA,) and not growing except in fruitful years: (M, TA:) or a certain herb, or plant, like curap [or millet]; (K;) or a certain herb having ears at its extremities like the ears of curap, (M, TA, *) and having reeds, (qSb [i. e. qaSab], M,) or twigs, (qDb [i. e. quDub], TA,) and leaves, growing in every place except in unmixed sand, [for HurRa AlrRamoli in the TA, I find in the M HawRa Alrumli,] and growing upon one stem and two stems: (M, TA:) or, accord. to AHn, a certain herb, having a jzrp [app. meaning rhizoma like the carrot], which is not eaten, and twigs bearing a fruit from the bottom thereof to the top thereof, having leaves like those of the Turoxuwn, agreeing well with the pasturing cattle, and having a small dust-coloured blossom upon which bees feed; (M, TA;) rising about the height of a man, (TA,) or half the height of a man; (M;) two whereof suffice to satiate a camel: (M, TA:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (M, K.)

cunubRaI c
cunubRaI and cinibRaI: see canabN, first sentence.

cunaAbN c
cunaAbN: see canabN, in two places.

cinaAbN c
cinaAbN: see canabN, in five places: ― -b2- and see also miconabN. ― -b3- Also A small cord with which a camel's tail is tied to his hind girth, lest he should swing about his tail and so dirt his rider. (M, K.)

canuwbN c
canuwbN A horse (T, S, &c.) having a long tail: (T, S:) or having a full, or an ample, tail. (M, A, K.) [See also OaconabN.] ― -b2- Hence applied to a day: see canabN, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b3- Also A great dalow [or bucket]: (Fr, T, Msb:) or one that has a canab↓ [or tail]: (TA:) or one that is full (S, M, Msb, K) of water; (S, Msb;) not applied to one that is empty: (S, TA:) or one that is nearly full of water: (ISk, S:) or one containing less than fills it: or one containing water: or a dalow (M, K) in any case: (M:) or a bucketful of water: (A:) masc. and fem.; (Fr, Lh, T, S, M, Msb;) sometimes the latter: (Lh, M:) pl. (of pauc., S) OaconibapN and (of mult., S) canaAYibu (S, M, K) and cinaAbN. (M, A, * Msb, K.) Fr. cites as an ex.,
lanaA canuwbN walakumo canuwbu
faUino Oabayotumo falanaA Alqaliybu
[as meaning For you shall be a great bucket, and for us a great bucket: or, if ye refuse this, for us shall be the well]. (T.) [Accord. to the K, it also signifies A grave: but this is evidently a mistake, which seems to have arisen from a misunderstanding of a statement by ISd, who says,] Aboo-Dhu-eyb uses it metaphorically in relation to a grave, calling it [i. e. the grave] a well, in his saying,
fakunotu canuwba AlbiYora lamRaA tabasRalato
wasurobilotu OakofaAniI wawusRidotu saAEidiI
[app. meaning (tropical:) And I was as though I were the corpse of the grave (lit. the bucket of the well) when she frowned, and clad with my grave-clothes, and made to recline upon my upper arm: for the corpse is laid in the grave upon its right side, or so inclined that the face is turned towards Mekkeh]. (M.) [And Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee- 'Áïdh El-Hudhalee, describing a wild he-ass and she-asses, likens to it a certain rate of running which he contrasts with another rate likened by him to a well such as is termed xasiyfN: see Kosegarten's “ Carmina Hudsailitarum, ” p. 189.] ― -b4- Hence metaphorically applied to (tropical:) Rain. (Ham p. 410.) ― -b5- [Hence, also,] (tropical:) A lot, share, or portion: (Fr, T, S, M, A, Msb, K:) [see the former of the two verses cited in this paragraph:] in this sense masc.: (Msb:) and in this sense it is used in the Kur li. last verse but one. (Fr, T, M.) ＝ -A2- Also (tropical:) The flesh of the [portion of the back next the back-bone, on either side, which is called the] maton: (M, K:) or the part where the maton ends; (M;) the flesh of the lower, or lowest, part of the maton: (S:) or the [buttocks, or parts called] Oaloyap and maOokim: (M, K:) or the flesh of the Oaloyap and maMkim: (CK:) and the canuwbaAni are the [two parts called the] matonaAni, (M, K,) on this side and on that [of the back-bone]: (M:) or canuwbu Almatoni means the flesh that is called yaraAbiyEu Almatoni [which are the portions of flesh next the back-bone, on either side thereof]. (A.)

cunayobN c
cunayobN [dim. of canabN: ＝ -A2- and] i. q. cunayobiIRN, q. v. (TA.)

dunaAbapN c
dunaAbapN The Oalof [i. e. toe, or foremost extremity, also called the Oasalap,] of a sandal. (K.) ― -b2- See also canabN, in six places. ― -b3- And see miconabN.

cinaAbapN c
cinaAbapN: see canabN, in six places: ― -b2- and see miconabN, in two places. ― -b3- cinaAbapN AlTRariyqi (assumed tropical:) The point, or place, to which the way, or road, leads; syn. wajohuhu. (IAar, M, K.) So in the saying of Abu-l-Jarráh, to a certain man, UinRaka lamo taroXado cinaAbapa AlTRariyqi [(assumed tropical:) Verily thou didst not follow a right course in
respect of the point, or place, to which the way that thou tookest leads]. (IAar, M.) ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) Relationship; nearness with respect to kindred; or near relationship. (K.)

cunaAbaI c
cunaAbaI: see canabN, in three places. ― -b2- It is also applied to Four [feathers] in the wing of a bird, after what are called AlxawafiI. (S.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad., mano maAta EalaI cunaAbaI TariyqK fahuwa mino Oaholihi, meaning [(assumed tropical:) Whosoever dies] purposing to pursue a way leading to some particular end, [he is to be reckoned as one of the people thereof.] (TA.) ＝ -A2- Accord. to Fr and the S, it signifies also A fluid like mucus that falls from the noses of camels: but this is a mistake: the right word, as stated by IB and others, is cunaAnaI. (L, MF, TA.)

cunayobaMCu c
cunayobaMCu A certain grain that is found in wheat, whereof the latter is cleared [by winnowing or other means]. (M, K.) [See also cunayonaMCu, in art. cn.]

cunayobiIRN c
cunayobiIRN (assumed tropical:) A certain kind of [the striped garments called] buruwd [pl. of burodN]; (AHeyth, K;) as also cunayobN↓. (TA.)

caAnibN c
caAnibN (tropical:) Following in the track of a thing. (TA.) See also canabN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

Oaconabu c
Oaconabu A [lizard of the kind called] DabR having a long tail. (T, L.) [See also canuwbN.]

taconuwbN c
taconuwbN and tuconuwbN, and with p: see 2.

maconabN c
maconabN: see the next paragraph.

miconabN c
miconabN A long tail. (IAar, T, K.) ― -b2- And [hence, app. for cuw miconabK], (T,) or mucanRibN↓, (TA, [but see this latter below,]) A [lizard of the kind called] DabR. (T, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (S, K,) or maconabN↓, like maqoEadN, (A,) and miconabapN↓, (M, TA,) (assumed tropical:) A ladle; (S, M, A, K;) because it has a tail, or what resembles a tail: (M:) pl. macaAnibu. (S, M.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A water-course, or channel of a torrent, in a tract at the foot of a mountain; (Lth, T, S, M, A, K;) not wide; (A;) or not very wide; (M;) or not very long and wide; (Lth, T;) as also cinaAbapN↓: (S:) the taloEap is in the lower part of a mountain (Lth, T, A) or in an acclivity: (Lth, T, S, A:) also a water-course or channel of a torrent, between what are termed taloEataAni; (TA; [see taloEapN, and see also madofaEN;]) or this is termed taloEap canabu↓; (T;) or it is termed cinaAbN↓, of which the pl. is canaAYibu: (M, K:) also a water-course, or channel of a torrent, [running] to a tract of land: (M, K:) and a rivulet, or streamlet, (K,) or the like thereof, (AHn, T, M,) flowing from one rawoDap [or meadow] to another, (AHn, T, M, K,) and separating therein; (T;) as also cunaAbapN↓ and cinaAbapN↓; (K;) and the tract over which this flows is also called miconabN. (T.) See also canabN, in the middle of the paragraph.

miconabapN c
miconabapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

mucanRibN c
mucanRibN [app. applied to a she-camel, accord. to the K, or perhaps to a lizard of the kind called DabR, as seems to be indicated in the TA,] Finding difficulty in parturition, and therefore stretching out her tail: (K:) [but accord. to Az,] it is applied to a DabR only when he is striking with his tail a hunter or a serpent desiring to catch him. (T.) See also miconabN. ― -b2- See also 2, in two places.

maconuwbN c
maconuwbN (tropical:) A man followed [by dependants]. (A.)

mucaAnibN c
mucaAnibN A camel that is at the rear of other camels; (K;) as also musotaconibN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 3.

saHaAbN mutacaAnibN c
saHaAbN mutacaAnibN (tropical:) Clouds following one another. (A.)

musotaconibN c
musotaconibN: see mucaAnibN. ― -b2- Also One who is at the tails of camels, (S, TA,) not quitting their track. (TA.)

ciho c
ciho and cihiI: see art. cA.

1 cahaba c
1. cahaba, (S, A, &c.,) aor.
cahaba
, (A, K,) inf. n. cahaAbN (S, A, Msb, K) and cihaAbN (TA) and cuhuwbN (S, A, K) and macohabN, (A, K,) He (a man, S, [and a beast,]) went [in any manner, or any pace]; went, or passed, along; marched; journeyed; proceeded: went, or passed, away; departed: syn. maXaI, (A,) or saAra, (K,) or marR: (S, A, K:) and said of a mark or trace or the like [as meaning it went away]. (Msb.) [And hence, (assumed tropical:) It wasted away; became consumed, destroyed, exhausted, spent, or expended.] ― -b2- cahaba Uilayohi He went, repaired, betook himself, or had recourse, to him, or it. (TA.) And they say also, cahaba AlXRaOoma [He went to Syria]; making the verb trans. without a particle; for although AlXOm is here a special adv. n., they liken it to a vague locality. (TA.) ― -b3- cahaba Eanohu He, or it, went from, quitted, relinquished, or left, him, or it. (TA.) ― -b4- cahaba fiIAlOaroDi, (A, Msb,) inf. n. cahaAbN and cuhuwbN and macohabN, He went away [into the country, or in the land]: (Msb:) [but it often means (assumed tropical:) he went into the open country, or out of doors, to satisfy a want of nature: or simply] (tropical:) he voided his excrement, or ordure. (A.) ― -b5- cahaba bihi He went, or went away, with him, or it: (A:) and he made him, or it, to go, go away, pass away, or depart; (A, Msb, K;) as also Achbhu↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) and bihi Achb↓, (K,) but this is rare; (Zj, TA;) and chRbhu↓, inf. n. tacohiybN: (MF:) [all may likewise be rendered he removed, dispelled, put away, or banished, it; properly and tropically: and (assumed tropical:) he made it to cease; made away with it, did away with it, made an end of it; wasted, consumed, destroyed, exhausted, spent, or expended, it; and these meanings may perhaps be intended by OazaAlahu, whereby the first is explained in the A and K, as are also the second and third in the K:] or, accord. to some, when cahaba is trans. by means of bi, accompaniment is necessarily signified; but not otherwise; so that if you say cahaba bihi, the meaning is, he went away with him, or it; i. e., accompanying him, or it; [he took away, or carried off or away, him, or it;] but if you say Achbhu↓ or chRbhu↓, the meaning is, he made him, or it, to go, go away, pass away, or depart, alone, without accompanying him, or it: this, however, is not agreeable with the phrase in the Kur [ii. 16], cahaba QllRehu binuwrihimo [though this may be well rendered God taketh away their light]. (MF, TA.) [Hence,] one says, Oayona yucohabu bika, which may mean (assumed tropical:) Where, or whither, wilt thou be taken away, and what will be done with thee and made to come to pass with thee, if this be thine intellect? or, accord. to Mtr, it is a saying of the people of Baghdád, addressed to him whom they charge with foolish judgment or opinion, as meaning Oayona yucohabu biEaqolika (assumed tropical:) [Where, or whither, is thine intellect taken away?]. (Har p. 574.) [In like manner one says, cahaba Eaqoluhu (assumed tropical:) His reason, or intellect, quitted him, or forsook him; he became bereft of his reason, or intellect. And cahaba fuWaAduhu (assumed tropical:) His heart forsook him, or failed him, by reason of fear or the like.] And cahaba laHomuhu (assumed tropical:) [His flesh wasted away]. (K in art. bHr, &c.) And cahaba AlrRajulu fiI Alqawomi (tropical:) The man became lost [or he disappeared] among the people, or party. (A.) And cahaba AlmaMCa fiI AllRabani (tropical:) The water became lost [or it disappeared] in the milk. (A.) ― -b6- cahaba Ealayohi (tropical:) It escaped his memory; he forgot it. (A, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, dubious, confused, or vague, to him. (MA.) ― -b7- cahaba macohabFA HasanFA (S, A, TA) (tropical:) He pursued a good way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like. (TA.) And cahaba fiI AldRiyni macohabFA (assumed tropical:) He formed, or held, an opinion, or a persuasion, or a belief, respecting religion: or, accord. to Es-Sarakustee, he introduced an innovation in religion. (Msb.) And cahaba macohaba fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) He pursued the way, course, mode, or manner, of acting &c. of such a one. (Msb.) And cahaba licahobihi and limacohabihi (tropical:) He pursued his way, course, mode, or manner, of acting &c. (JK, TA.) And cahaba UilaI macohabK (tropical:) He betook himself to [or took to or held] a belief, a creed, a persuasion, a doctrine, an opinion, a tenet, or a body of tenets or articles of belief. (K, TA.) And fulaAnN yacohabu UilaI qawoli OabiI Haniyfapa (tropical:) Such a one takes to, or holds, [the saying, or] the belief, creed, persuasion, doctrine, &c., of Aboo-Haneefeh. (A.) [And cahaba UilaI OanRa AlOamora kacaA (assumed tropical:) He held, or was of opinion, that the thing, or affair, or case, was so. And cahaba bilafoZK UilaIlafoZK Mxara (assumed tropical:) He regarded a word, or an expression, in his manner of using it, as equivalent to another word, or expression; as, for instance, when one makes a fem. noun masc. because it is syn. with a noun that is masc., or makes a verb trans. by means of a certain perticle because it is syn. with a verb that is trans. by means of that same particle: and also (assumed tropical:) he regarded a word, or an expression, as etymologically relating, or traceable, to another word, or expression. And cahaba bihi UilaI maEonaI kacaA (assumed tropical:) He regarded it, or used it, (i. e. a word, or an expression,) as relating to such a meaning, or as
meaning such a thing.] ― -b8- cahaba fiI Talabi AlXRaIoCi kulRa macohabK (assumed tropical:) [He tried every way, or did his utmost, in seeking the thing]. (K in art. mwt.) And cahaba fiIAllRiyni kulRa macohabK (assumed tropical:) [It attained the utmost degree of softness]: said of the skin. (TA in that art.) ― -b9- Aicohabo Uilayoka (assumed tropical:) Betake, or apply, thyself to thine own affairs; or occupy thyself therewith. (T and K * voce UilaI.) ― -b10- cahaba UilaI Oabiyhi fiI AlXRabahi i. q. nazaEa (assumed tropical:) [He inclined to his father in likeness; resembled him; or had a natural likeness to him]. (S in art. nzE.) ＝ -A2- cahiba, (S, K,) aor.
cahaba
